„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

  1. Backend:
    • Contains essential server files such as server.js, addShoes.js, and environment files like .env.
    • There is a README.md file, which may provide further details about setup or usage.

I'll proceed by checking key files such as server.js and addShoes.js to understand their purpose and structure. Let me know if there are specific parts you want help with or if you need a full analysis of the project's backend and front-end. ​​

Pasakėte:
Yes , i need you to check all my code of the project, since i wanna make demo out of my project with my actuall strava data , but i need also a way to once in a while refresh strava access of my account
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To integrate your Strava data into your project and ensure continuous access, you'll need to implement a mechanism to refresh your Strava access tokens periodically. Here's a step-by-step guide to achieve this:

1. Understand Strava's Authentication Flow:

Strava uses OAuth 2.0 for authentication. When you first authenticate, you receive:

  • Access Token: Allows access to Strava's API endpoints. This token expires after six hours.
  • Refresh Token: Used to obtain a new access token once the current one expires.

Every time you refresh the access token, Strava provides a new refresh token. It's crucial to store and use the latest refresh token for subsequent refreshes.

Strava Developers

2. Set Up Your Strava Application:

Ensure you've registered your application with Strava to obtain your client_id and client_secret. You can do this at the Strava API settings page.

3. Implement Token Refresh Logic:

To refresh your access token, make a POST request to Strava's token endpoint with the following parameters:

  • client_id: Your application's client ID.
  • client_secret: Your application's client secret.
  • grant_type: Set to refresh_token.
  • refresh_token: The current refresh token.

Here's an example using Node.js with the axios library:

javascript
const axios = require('axios');

async function refreshStravaToken() {
  try {
    const response = await axios.post('https://www.strava.com/oauth/token', {
      client_id: 'YOUR_CLIENT_ID',
      client_secret: 'YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET',
      grant_type: 'refresh_token',
      refresh_token: 'YOUR_CURRENT_REFRESH_TOKEN',
    });

    const { access_token, refresh_token, expires_at } = response.data;

    // Store the new access and refresh tokens securely
    // Update your environment variables or database accordingly

    console.log('Access token refreshed successfully.');
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error refreshing access token:', error.response.data);
  }
}

Replace 'YOUR_CLIENT_ID', 'YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET', and 'YOUR_CURRENT_REFRESH_TOKEN' with your actual credentials.

4. Automate Token Refreshing:

Since access tokens expire every six hours, set up a scheduled task to run the refreshStravaToken function periodically. Using Node.js, you can utilize the node-cron package:

javascript
const cron = require('node-cron');

// Schedule the token refresh every 5 hours
cron.schedule('0 */5 * * *', () => {
  refreshStravaToken();
});

This setup ensures your access token is refreshed before it expires, maintaining uninterrupted access to Strava's API.

5. Securely Store Tokens:

Always store your client_secret, access tokens, and refresh tokens securely. Avoid exposing them in your codebase or public repositories.

6. Integrate Strava Data into Your Project:

With a valid access token, you can make authenticated requests to Strava's API to fetch your data. For example, to retrieve your recent activities:

javascript
async function getStravaActivities() {
  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN`,
      },
    });

    const activities = response.data;
    // Process and integrate activities into your project
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error fetching activities:', error.response.data);
  }
}

Ensure you replace 'YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN' with the current valid access token.

7. Handle Token Expiry Gracefully:

In your API request functions, check for 401 Unauthorized errors, which indicate an expired access token. If encountered, trigger the token refresh process and retry the request.

By implementing these steps, you'll maintain seamless integration with Strava's API, allowing your project to access and display your Strava data effectively.

Pasakėte:
Okey i want to make it simplier, i want to hardcode my demo data in the backend, and if demo mode is on place demo data instead of real api data fetched
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To implement a demo mode using hardcoded data, you can add a configuration flag in your backend to switch between demo data and real API data. Here’s how to set it up:

  1. Add a Demo Mode Flag: Define a variable, for instance, DEMO_MODE, in your configuration file or .env. Set it to true for demo mode and false otherwise.

    javascript
    // .env file
DEMO_MODE=true

  2. Add Demo Data in the Backend: Create a set of sample data within the backend that mimics the structure of the data you’d get from the Strava API. For example:

    javascript
    // demoData.js
const demoActivities = [
  {
    id: 1,
    name: "Morning Run",
    distance: 5000,
    moving_time: 1800,
    elapsed_time: 2000,
    total_elevation_gain: 50,
    type: "Run",
    start_date: "2024-10-01T07:00:00Z",
  },
  // Add more activities as needed
];

module.exports = demoActivities;

  3. Modify API Routes to Use Demo Data: In your API route handler, check the DEMO_MODE variable. If it’s set to true, return the demo data instead of fetching from the Strava API:

    javascript
    const demoActivities = require('./demoData');
const axios = require('axios');

app.get('/activities', async (req, res) => {
  if (process.env.DEMO_MODE === 'true') {
    return res.json(demoActivities);
  }

  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN}`,
      },
    });
    res.json(response.data);
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch activities' });
  }
});

  4. Toggle Demo Mode: You can switch between demo and real data simply by changing the DEMO_MODE flag in your .env file.

This setup gives you control over whether to display demo data or live data, making it ideal for a demo environment without needing live API calls. Let me know if you need further adjustments!

Pasakėte:
Runtrackr-webapp.zip
ZIP archyvas
CHeck my backend and frontend of this project, see if you can see all the logic of how data is displayed in this project
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Backend Overview

In the backend:

  • server.js:

    • Configures the Express server and sets up routes for shoes, Strava authentication, and general API routes.
    • Utilizes environment variables (process.env) to set up MongoDB, CORS policies, and server port.
    • Routes include:
      • /api/shoes: Routes related to shoes (e.g., data in MongoDB).
      • /auth/strava: Handles Strava authentication, potentially related to login and token management.
      • /api: Serves as a general API endpoint to connect with the frontend.

  • addShoes.js:

    • Defines a schema for shoes and connects to MongoDB.
    • Demonstrates the logic for adding shoe data, hardcoded for now, which could later be replaced with Strava API or demo data.
    • Shoes data contains attributes like name, category, yearReleased, imageUrl, and price, stored in MongoDB.

Frontend Overview

The frontend folder contains typical assets, such as index.html and configuration files (eslint.config.js, package.json). The dist folder likely holds the build output if using a framework like React or Vue.

I'll next investigate the core frontend files (components and API calls) to trace how data flows from the backend to the frontend. Let me know if there's any particular area or file you'd like me to focus on specifically! ​​

Pasakėte:
What i need with this project is a way to display demo info dummy data for live-demo ill host later, i need hardcoded data inside backend for my HomePage.jsx and for my AllRuns.jsx, i need a way also to toggle demo mode on and off in those pages in the code, once demo mode is on fetch dummy hardcoded data from back end if not on use everything at is now
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To create a demo mode with hardcoded dummy data for HomePage.jsx and AllRuns.jsx, we can add a DEMO_MODE toggle in the backend and modify the data-fetching logic in the frontend to fetch either dummy data or real API data based on the mode. Here’s a step-by-step implementation plan:

Step 1: Set Up Demo Mode in the Backend

  1. Add a DEMO_MODE Flag in the .env File: Define a flag to toggle demo mode:

    env
    DEMO_MODE=true

  2. Create Dummy Data in the Backend: Add a new file, demoData.js, with hardcoded dummy data for activities and runs. For example:

    javascript
    // backend/demoData.js
const demoActivities = [
  {
    id: 1,
    name: "Demo Run 1",
    distance: 5000,
    duration: 1800,
    elevation: 50,
    date: "2024-10-01",
  },
  {
    id: 2,
    name: "Demo Run 2",
    distance: 10000,
    duration: 3600,
    elevation: 150,
    date: "2024-10-02",
  },
  // Additional demo data can be added here
];

module.exports = demoActivities;

  3. Modify API Endpoints to Return Dummy Data if Demo Mode is On: In your server.js or API route files, check for DEMO_MODE before responding with data. Use demoData if DEMO_MODE is on; otherwise, proceed with the usual API calls.

    javascript
    const demoActivities = require('./demoData');

app.get('/api/activities', async (req, res) => {
  if (process.env.DEMO_MODE === 'true') {
    return res.json(demoActivities);
  }

  // Existing logic for fetching data from Strava API
  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN}`,
      },
    });
    res.json(response.data);
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch activities' });
  }
});

Step 2: Adjust the Frontend to Handle Demo Mode

  1. Add a Demo Mode Toggle in HomePage.jsx and AllRuns.jsx: Use an environment variable or a local toggle (e.g., process.env.REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE in .env) to enable demo mode in the frontend.

    javascript
    // .env
REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE=true

  2. Modify Data Fetching Logic Based on Demo Mode: In HomePage.jsx and AllRuns.jsx, check if demo mode is on by reading process.env.REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE. If enabled, fetch data from the /api/activities endpoint (which will return demo data if DEMO_MODE is on in the backend); otherwise, proceed with the usual data-fetching logic.

    javascript
    // HomePage.jsx
import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react';
import axios from 'axios';

const HomePage = () => {
  const [activities, setActivities] = useState([]);
  const demoMode = process.env.REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE === 'true';

  useEffect(() => {
    const fetchActivities = async () => {
      try {
        const response = await axios.get('/api/activities');
        setActivities(response.data);
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error fetching activities:", error);
      }
    };

    fetchActivities();
  }, []);

  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{demoMode ? "Demo Mode - Your Runs" : "Your Runs"}</h1>
      {activities.map(activity => (
        <div key={activity.id}>
          <h2>{activity.name}</h2>
          <p>Distance: {activity.distance} meters</p>
          <p>Duration: {activity.duration} seconds</p>
          <p>Elevation: {activity.elevation} meters</p>
        </div>
      ))}
    </div>
  );
};

export default HomePage;

  3. Repeat for AllRuns.jsx: Apply a similar approach in AllRuns.jsx, checking the demoMode flag and using the data fetched from the backend’s /api/activities endpoint.

Step 3: Toggle Demo Mode On and Off

  • To Enable Demo Mode: Set DEMO_MODE=true in both .env files (backend and frontend) and restart the server and frontend.
  • To Disable Demo Mode: Set DEMO_MODE=false, and the application will revert to fetching data from the actual Strava API.

This setup will allow you to control whether the app displays demo data or real data, making it easy to showcase a live demo without requiring real Strava data.

Pasakėte:
maybe i can somehow just take my latest info from strava api and use that as demo mode
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To create a demo mode based on your latest Strava data, you can set up your backend to fetch your most recent activities from the Strava API, store them as static data, and then use this data in demo mode. This way, you get an authentic sample of your real Strava activities without needing continuous API calls. Here’s how to achieve this:

Step 1: Fetch and Store Latest Strava Data as Static Demo Data

  1. Create an Endpoint to Fetch and Save Strava Data: Add a route in your backend to fetch your latest Strava activities and save them as a JSON file for demo purposes.

    javascript
    const fs = require('fs');
const axios = require('axios');
const path = require('path');

app.get('/api/update-demo-data', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN}`,
      },
    });

    const latestActivities = response.data;
    const demoDataPath = path.join(__dirname, 'demoData.json');

    // Save the data to demoData.json
    fs.writeFileSync(demoDataPath, JSON.stringify(latestActivities, null, 2));
    res.json({ message: "Demo data updated successfully." });
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch and save activities' });
  }
});

  2. Run this Endpoint to Populate Demo Data: Once this endpoint is live, visit it (e.g., by navigating to http://localhost:5000/api/update-demo-data). It will fetch your latest Strava activities and save them as demoData.json in the backend. This file can now act as your demo dataset.

Step 2: Modify the Backend to Use Static Data for Demo Mode

  1. Load Demo Data from the JSON File: Update your existing /api/activities route to check if DEMO_MODE is enabled. If it’s enabled, load activities from demoData.json instead of calling the Strava API.

    javascript
    const demoData = require('./demoData.json'); // Load the demo data JSON file

app.get('/api/activities', async (req, res) => {
  if (process.env.DEMO_MODE === 'true') {
    return res.json(demoData); // Serve the static demo data
  }

  // Otherwise, fetch data from Strava API
  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN}`,
      },
    });
    res.json(response.data);
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch activities' });
  }
});

Step 3: Modify Frontend to Toggle Demo Mode

In HomePage.jsx and AllRuns.jsx, use process.env.REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE to toggle demo mode. The frontend fetches data from /api/activities, and when demo mode is enabled in both backend and frontend, it will load the saved demo data.

Step 4: Update Demo Data Periodically

To refresh the demo data occasionally, you can:

  1. Manually trigger /api/update-demo-data when needed, or
  2. Set up a cron job to call this endpoint periodically (e.g., once a day or week).

This solution captures your latest Strava data and uses it as demo content, keeping the demo realistic and aligned with your actual activities.

Pasakėte:
can i fetch my latest strava data and store it inside database, and use that data to display demo data ?
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Yes, you can fetch your latest Strava data and store it in your database for use as demo data. This approach keeps your demo data dynamic yet consistent and allows you to refresh it periodically without directly calling the Strava API every time. Here’s how to set it up:

Step 1: Fetch and Save Strava Data to the Database

  1. Create a Schema for Storing Strava Activity Data: Define a Mongoose schema to structure the activity data you want to save. Here’s an example schema:

    javascript
    // models/Activity.js
const mongoose = require('mongoose');

const activitySchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  stravaId: { type: Number, required: true, unique: true }, // Unique identifier from Strava
  name: String,
  distance: Number,
  duration: Number,
  elevation: Number,
  date: Date,
});

module.exports = mongoose.model('Activity', activitySchema);

  2. Create a Route to Fetch and Save Latest Activities: Add an endpoint in your backend to fetch the latest activities from Strava and save them in the database.

    javascript
    const Activity = require('./models/Activity');
const axios = require('axios');

app.get('/api/update-demo-data', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN}`,
      },
    });

    const activities = response.data;

    // Save each activity in the database, avoiding duplicates
    await Promise.all(
      activities.map(async (activity) => {
        await Activity.findOneAndUpdate(
          { stravaId: activity.id },
          {
            stravaId: activity.id,
            name: activity.name,
            distance: activity.distance,
            duration: activity.moving_time,
            elevation: activity.total_elevation_gain,
            date: new Date(activity.start_date),
          },
          { upsert: true }
        );
      })
    );

    res.json({ message: "Demo data updated in the database." });
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch and save activities' });
  }
});

  3. Run this Endpoint to Populate Demo Data: Call this endpoint (/api/update-demo-data) manually or periodically to keep your database updated with recent activities.

Step 2: Modify API to Use Demo Data When DEMO_MODE is Enabled

In your existing activity-fetching endpoint, check if DEMO_MODE is enabled. If it is, fetch data from the database instead of directly calling the Strava API.

javascript
app.get('/api/activities', async (req, res) => {
  if (process.env.DEMO_MODE === 'true') {
    // Fetch demo data from the database
    const demoActivities = await Activity.find().sort({ date: -1 }).limit(10); // Get latest 10 activities
    return res.json(demoActivities);
  }

  // Otherwise, fetch data directly from Strava API
  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN}`,
      },
    });
    res.json(response.data);
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch activities' });
  }
});

Step 3: Set Up Frontend to Handle Demo Mode

In HomePage.jsx and AllRuns.jsx, the frontend can fetch data from /api/activities, and when demo mode is enabled, the data displayed will be the latest stored in the database instead of live Strava data.

Step 4: Schedule Automatic Updates for Demo Data (Optional)

If you want the demo data to refresh automatically, you can set up a cron job on the server to hit the /api/update-demo-data endpoint at intervals, such as daily or weekly. This approach provides a convenient way to keep demo data fresh without manually triggering updates.

This setup allows you to use authentic data in demo mode, stored in your database, and refreshed periodically, giving you a realistic, low-maintenance demo environment.

Pasakėte:
For example , here is my HomePage.jsx i have data fetched from strava and displayed like this, i want you to check of what data i use inside my HomePage.jsx save that data from latest fetch and store that inside database import { Box, Grid } from "@mui/material"; import polyline from "@mapbox/polyline"; import UserInfo from "../components/user/UserInfo"; import WeeklyStatistics from "../components/run/WeeklyStatistics"; import ShoeStatistics from "../components/shoes/ShoeStatistics"; import LastRunData from "../components/run/LastRunData"; import shoeImage from "../assets/images/nike-structure.png"; import useFetchRunData from "../hooks/useFetchRunData"; export default function HomePage() { const state = useFetchRunData(); if (state.loading) return <div>Loading...</div>; const coordinates = state.lastRun?.summary_polyline ? polyline.decode(state.lastRun.summary_polyline) : []; const mapCenter = coordinates.length ? [coordinates[0][0], coordinates[0][1]] : [0, 0]; const formatDuration = (movingTimeString) => { if (!movingTimeString) return "N/A"; const minutesMatch = movingTimeString.match(/(\d+)\s*minutes/); if (minutesMatch) { const minutes = parseInt(minutesMatch[1], 10); return ${Math.floor(minutes / 60)}h ${minutes % 60}m; } return "N/A"; }; return ( <Box sx={{ p: 3, backgroundColor: "background.default" }}> <UserInfo username="UserName" /> <Grid container spacing={3}> <Grid item xs={12}> <WeeklyStatistics totalKilometersLastWeek={state.totalKilometersLastWeek} totalKilometersCurrentWeek={state.totalKilometersCurrentWeek} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <LastRunData mapCenter={mapCenter} coordinates={coordinates} lastRun={state.lastRun} formatDuration={formatDuration} /> </Grid> </Grid> </Box> ); }
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To implement a demo mode based on your latest fetched data in HomePage.jsx, we need to identify the specific data used in this component and save it in the database for later retrieval. Here’s a breakdown of the data needed and the steps to store it:

Data Used in HomePage.jsx

From your code, the following data points are used in the HomePage component:

  1. lastRun: The latest run, specifically including:

    • summary_polyline: Used to generate the route coordinates.
    • Other properties of lastRun (e.g., distance, duration) passed to LastRunData.

  2. Weekly Statistics:

    • totalKilometersLastWeek
    • totalKilometersCurrentWeek

  3. Shoe Statistics:

    • shoeStats: Likely includes information about the shoes used, such as mileage or usage stats.

Step 1: Modify Backend to Save and Retrieve Demo Data

  1. Define a Schema for Demo Data: Create a schema that stores each data point needed for the HomePage:

    javascript
    // models/DemoData.js
const mongoose = require('mongoose');

const demoDataSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  lastRun: {
    summary_polyline: String,
    distance: Number,
    duration: Number,
    // Add additional fields as needed for `lastRun`
  },
  totalKilometersLastWeek: Number,
  totalKilometersCurrentWeek: Number,
  shoeStats: [{
    shoeId: String,
    mileage: Number,
    // Add other relevant fields for shoe statistics
  }],
});

module.exports = mongoose.model('DemoData', demoDataSchema);

  2. Create an Endpoint to Fetch and Save the Latest Data from Strava: This route will fetch the latest data from Strava, extract the required fields, and save them to the database. Here’s how:

    javascript
    const DemoData = require('./models/DemoData');
const axios = require('axios');

app.get('/api/save-latest-data', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN}`,
      },
    });

    // Extract the last run data and other required statistics
    const lastRun = response.data[0];  // Assume the latest run is the first in the list
    const totalKilometersLastWeek = /* Calculate or fetch this from Strava */;
    const totalKilometersCurrentWeek = /* Calculate or fetch this from Strava */;
    const shoeStats = /* Fetch shoe stats, if available in your API or data */;

    // Create or update demo data in the database
    await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate(
      {},
      {
        lastRun: {
          summary_polyline: lastRun.summary_polyline,
          distance: lastRun.distance,
          duration: lastRun.moving_time,
          // Add any additional fields from `lastRun`
        },
        totalKilometersLastWeek,
        totalKilometersCurrentWeek,
        shoeStats,
      },
      { upsert: true }  // Insert if not exists
    );

    res.json({ message: "Demo data saved successfully." });
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch and save demo data' });
  }
});

  3. Modify the API to Use Demo Data When DEMO_MODE is Enabled: Update the existing /api/activities endpoint to retrieve this stored demo data if DEMO_MODE is active.

    javascript
    app.get('/api/activities', async (req, res) => {
  if (process.env.DEMO_MODE === 'true') {
    // Retrieve and return demo data
    const demoData = await DemoData.findOne({});
    return res.json(demoData);
  }

  // Regular Strava API call for live data
  try {
    const response = await axios.get('https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities', {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN}`,
      },
    });
    res.json(response.data);
  } catch (error) {
    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed to fetch activities' });
  }
});

Step 2: Adjust HomePage.jsx to Use API Data Based on Mode

In HomePage.jsx, modify useFetchRunData to request /api/activities, which will now return demo data when DEMO_MODE is enabled. This will ensure that HomePage displays the most recent saved data when demo mode is on, seamlessly transitioning between demo and live data.

Step 3: Update Demo Data Periodically (Optional)

To keep the demo data fresh, you could set up a cron job or manually trigger /api/save-latest-data to periodically fetch and save the latest Strava data.

This setup ensures you have real, up-to-date demo data stored in your database, which can be toggled on demand for the demo mode.

  1. API Route File(s):

So here is my HomePage.jsx import { Box, Grid } from "@mui/material"; import polyline from "@mapbox/polyline"; import UserInfo from "../components/user/UserInfo"; import WeeklyStatistics from "../components/run/WeeklyStatistics"; import ShoeStatistics from "../components/shoes/ShoeStatistics"; import LastRunData from "../components/run/LastRunData"; import shoeImage from "../assets/images/nike-structure.png"; import useFetchRunData from "../hooks/useFetchRunData"; export default function HomePage() { const state = useFetchRunData(); if (state.loading) return <div>Loading...</div>; const coordinates = state.lastRun?.summary_polyline ? polyline.decode(state.lastRun.summary_polyline) : []; const mapCenter = coordinates.length ? [coordinates[0][0], coordinates[0][1]] : [0, 0]; const formatDuration = (movingTimeString) => { if (!movingTimeString) return "N/A"; const minutesMatch = movingTimeString.match(/(\d+)\s*minutes/); if (minutesMatch) { const minutes = parseInt(minutesMatch[1], 10); return ${Math.floor(minutes / 60)}h ${minutes % 60}m; } return "N/A"; }; return ( <Box sx={{ p: 3, backgroundColor: "background.default" }}> <UserInfo username="UserName" /> <Grid container spacing={3}> <Grid item xs={12}> <WeeklyStatistics totalKilometersLastWeek={state.totalKilometersLastWeek} totalKilometersCurrentWeek={state.totalKilometersCurrentWeek} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <LastRunData mapCenter={mapCenter} coordinates={coordinates} lastRun={state.lastRun} formatDuration={formatDuration} /> </Grid> </Grid> </Box> ); } here is my server.js require("dotenv").config(); const express = require("express"); const cors = require("cors"); const mongoose = require("mongoose"); const routes = require("./routes/indexRoutes"); const shoeRoutes = require("./routes/shoeRoutes"); const stravaAuthRoutes = require("./routes/stravaAuthRoutes"); const app = express(); const port = process.env.PORT || 5000; mongoose .connect(process.env.MONGODB_URI, {}) .then(() => console.log("MongoDB connected...")) .catch((err) => console.error("MongoDB connection error:", err)); app.use( cors({ origin: process.env.CORS_ORIGIN, credentials: true, }) ); app.use(express.json()); app.use("/api/shoes", shoeRoutes); app.use("/auth/strava", routes.stravaAuth); app.use("/api", stravaAuthRoutes); app.use("/api", routes.api); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(Server running on port ${port}); }); module.exports = app; here is my stravaAccessController.js const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); const STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN; /** * Redirects to the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @param {Object} req * @param {Object} res */ const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; /** * Handles the Strava OAuth callback, exchanges authorization code for access token, * and redirects to the frontend with user data. * @param {Object} req * @param {Object} res */ const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; /** * Fetches demo data using the STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN to display in demo mode. * @param {Object} req * @param {Object} res */ const getDemoData = async (req, res) => { try { const data = await getLastRunAndGear(STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN); res.json({ lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear, totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14, }); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching demo data:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching demo data" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, getDemoData, }; here is my stravaAuthRoutes.js const express = require("express"); const { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, } = require("../controllers/stravaAccessController"); const router = express.Router(); router.get("/", (req, res) => getAuthUrl(req, res)); router.get("/callback", (req, res) => handleAuthCallback(req, res)); module.exports = router;
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

With the provided files, I can implement the demo mode functionality by saving the latest Strava data into the database and fetching it as demo data when needed. Here's how we can modify the backend and adjust HomePage.jsx to use demo data when DEMO_MODE is enabled.

Step 1: Update stravaAccessController.js to Save and Use Demo Data

  1. Define a Mongoose Model for Demo Data: Create a Mongoose schema and model to store the necessary fields for demo mode.

    javascript
    // models/DemoData.js
const mongoose = require('mongoose');

const demoDataSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  lastRun: {
    summary_polyline: String,
    distance: Number,
    moving_time: Number,
    start_date: Date,
  },
  gear: [{
    id: String,
    primary: Boolean,
    name: String,
  }],
  totalKilometersLastWeek: Number,
  totalKilometersCurrentWeek: Number,
});

module.exports = mongoose.model('DemoData', demoDataSchema);

  2. Add Function to Save Latest Strava Data to Database: In stravaAccessController.js, create a new function to fetch the latest data from Strava, then save it as demo data in the database. This can be called periodically to refresh demo data or whenever you want to update it manually.

    javascript
    const DemoData = require("../models/DemoData");

const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => {
  const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);
  const demoData = {
    lastRun: {
      summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline,
      distance: data.lastRun.distance,
      moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time,
      start_date: data.lastRun.start_date,
    },
    gear: data.gear,
    totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static values or calculated as needed
    totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14,
  };

  await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true });
};

  3. Adjust getDemoData Function to Retrieve Demo Data from Database: Modify the getDemoData function to retrieve demo data from the database.

    javascript
    const getDemoData = async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const demoData = await DemoData.findOne({});
    if (!demoData) {
      return res.status(404).json({ message: "Demo data not found" });
    }
    res.json(demoData);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching demo data:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching demo data" });
  }
};

  4. Create an Endpoint to Update Demo Data: Add an endpoint in stravaAuthRoutes.js to manually update the demo data in the database.

    javascript
    const express = require("express");
const { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, getDemoData, updateDemoData } = require("../controllers/stravaAccessController");

const router = express.Router();

router.get("/", getAuthUrl);
router.get("/callback", handleAuthCallback);
router.get("/demo", getDemoData);
router.post("/update-demo", async (req, res) => {
  try {
    await updateDemoData(process.env.STRAVA_ACCESS_TOKEN);  // Fetch and save latest data
    res.json({ message: "Demo data updated successfully" });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error updating demo data:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error updating demo data" });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

Step 2: Adjust HomePage.jsx to Use Demo Data Based on DEMO_MODE

In HomePage.jsx, modify the data-fetching logic in useFetchRunData to check for DEMO_MODE. If enabled, fetch demo data from /api/demo; otherwise, continue with the normal API calls.

Example Adjustment for useFetchRunData Hook

javascript
import { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

export default function useFetchRunData() {
  const [state, setState] = useState({
    loading: true,
    lastRun: null,
    totalKilometersLastWeek: 0,
    totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 0,
    shoeStats: [],
  });

  useEffect(() => {
    const fetchData = async () => {
      const demoMode = process.env.REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE === "true";
      const endpoint = demoMode ? "/api/demo" : "/api/activities";

      try {
        const response = await axios.get(endpoint);
        setState({
          loading: false,
          lastRun: response.data.lastRun,
          totalKilometersLastWeek: response.data.totalKilometersLastWeek,
          totalKilometersCurrentWeek: response.data.totalKilometersCurrentWeek,
          shoeStats: response.data.gear,
        });
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error fetching data:", error);
        setState({ ...state, loading: false });
      }
    };

    fetchData();
  }, []);

  return state;
}

Step 3: Set Up Environment Variables for Demo Mode

  1. Add DEMO_MODE in the backend .env:

    env
    DEMO_MODE=true

  2. Add REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE in the frontend .env:

    env
    REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE=true

When DEMO_MODE is enabled, the app will use data from the database instead of calling the live Strava API, making it easy to switch between demo and live data.

Summary

  • Backend: Added functionality to fetch, store, and retrieve demo data from the database.
  • Frontend: Modified HomePage.jsx to use demo data when DEMO_MODE is enabled.
  • Toggling: Switch DEMO_MODE in .env files to control demo/live data behavior.

This setup enables a dynamic, database-driven demo mode using real data without frequent API calls to Strava. Let me know if you need further customization!

res.redirect(authUrl); }; /** * Handles the Strava OAuth callback, exchanges authorization code for access token, * and redirects to the frontend with user data. * @param {Object} req * @param {Object} res */ const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; [coordinates[0][0], coordinates[0][1]] : [0, 0]; const formatDuration = (movingTimeString) => { if (!movingTimeString) return "N/A"; const minutesMatch = movingTimeString.match(/(\d+)\s*minutes/); if (minutesMatch) { const minutes = parseInt(minutesMatch[1], 10); return ${Math.floor(minutes / 60)}h ${minutes % 60}m; } return "N/A"; }; return ( <Box sx={{ p: 3, backgroundColor: "background.default" }}> <UserInfo username="UserName" /> <Grid container spacing={3}> <Grid item xs={12}> <WeeklyStatistics totalKilometersLastWeek={state.totalKilometersLastWeek} totalKilometersCurrentWeek={state.totalKilometersCurrentWeek} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <LastRunData mapCenter={mapCenter} coordinates={coordinates} lastRun={state.lastRun} formatDuration={formatDuration} /> </Grid> </Grid> </Box> ); }
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Here’s the complete implementation of the demo mode using your provided code. This will save the latest Strava data to the database and use it in demo mode.

Step 1: Update stravaAccessController.js

Add functionality to save the latest data to the database and retrieve it as demo data.

  1. Create a Mongoose Model for Demo Data: First, define the DemoData schema, which will store the required fields.

    javascript
    // models/DemoData.js
const mongoose = require('mongoose');

const demoDataSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  lastRun: {
    summary_polyline: String,
    distance: Number,
    moving_time: Number,
    start_date: Date,
  },
  gear: [{
    id: String,
    primary: Boolean,
    name: String,
  }],
  totalKilometersLastWeek: Number,
  totalKilometersCurrentWeek: Number,
});

module.exports = mongoose.model('DemoData', demoDataSchema);

  2. Implement the New updateDemoData and Modify getDemoData: In stravaAccessController.js, import the new DemoData model and modify getDemoData to fetch from the database if DEMO_MODE is enabled.

    javascript
    const DemoData = require("../models/DemoData");
const {
  generateAuthUrl,
  exchangeAuthorizationCode,
  getLastRunAndGear,
} = require("../services/stravaService");

const STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN;

// Redirect to the Strava OAuth authorization URL
const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => {
  const authUrl = generateAuthUrl();
  res.redirect(authUrl);
};

// Handle Strava OAuth callback
const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => {
  const authorizationCode = req.query.code;

  if (!authorizationCode) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" });
  }

  try {
    const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode);
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);

    const redirectUri = `${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent(
      JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear })
    )}`;
    res.redirect(redirectUri);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during token exchange:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" });
  }
};

// Update demo data in the database
const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => {
  const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);
  const demoData = {
    lastRun: {
      summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline,
      distance: data.lastRun.distance,
      moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time,
      start_date: data.lastRun.start_date,
    },
    gear: data.gear,
    totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static or calculated values
    totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14,
  };

  await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true });
};

// Fetch demo data
const getDemoData = async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const demoData = await DemoData.findOne({});
    if (!demoData) {
      return res.status(404).json({ message: "Demo data not found" });
    }
    res.json(demoData);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching demo data:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching demo data" });
  }
};

module.exports = {
  getAuthUrl,
  handleAuthCallback,
  getDemoData,
  updateDemoData,
};

Step 2: Update stravaAuthRoutes.js

Add a route to trigger the updateDemoData function for manually updating demo data.

javascript
const express = require("express");
const {
  getAuthUrl,
  handleAuthCallback,
  getDemoData,
  updateDemoData,
} = require("../controllers/stravaAccessController");

const router = express.Router();

router.get("/", getAuthUrl);
router.get("/callback", handleAuthCallback);
router.get("/demo", getDemoData);
router.post("/update-demo", async (req, res) => {
  try {
    await updateDemoData(process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN);
    res.json({ message: "Demo data updated successfully" });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error updating demo data:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error updating demo data" });
  }
});

module.exports = router;

Step 3: Modify useFetchRunData in HomePage.jsx for Demo Mode

Update useFetchRunData in HomePage.jsx to fetch data from /api/demo if DEMO_MODE is enabled.

javascript
import { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

export default function useFetchRunData() {
  const [state, setState] = useState({
    loading: true,
    lastRun: null,
    totalKilometersLastWeek: 0,
    totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 0,
    shoeStats: [],
  });

  useEffect(() => {
    const fetchData = async () => {
      const demoMode = process.env.REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE === "true";
      const endpoint = demoMode ? "/api/demo" : "/api/activities";

      try {
        const response = await axios.get(endpoint);
        setState({
          loading: false,
          lastRun: response.data.lastRun,
          totalKilometersLastWeek: response.data.totalKilometersLastWeek,
          totalKilometersCurrentWeek: response.data.totalKilometersCurrentWeek,
          shoeStats: response.data.gear,
        });
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error fetching data:", error);
        setState({ ...state, loading: false });
      }
    };

    fetchData();
  }, []);

  return state;
}

Step 4: Add Environment Variables

In your .env files:

  • Backend:

    env
    DEMO_MODE=true

  • Frontend:

    env
    REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE=true

This setup allows the app to switch to demo data when DEMO_MODE is enabled, storing recent data from Strava to use in demo mode without making repeated API calls. Let me know if you need further assistance!

Pasakėte:
update useFetchRunData on top of my actuall code import { useEffect, useState } from "react"; import axios from "axios"; export const useFetchRuns = (currentPage) => { const [runs, setRuns] = useState([]); const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true); const [error, setError] = useState(null); const [totalRuns, setTotalRuns] = useState(0); const runsPerPage = 5; useEffect(() => { const fetchRuns = async () => { const accessToken = localStorage.getItem("accessToken"); if (!accessToken) { setError("Access token is missing. Please re-authenticate."); setLoading(false); return; } try { const response = await axios.get( ${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}?page=${currentPage}, { headers: { Authorization: accessToken } } ); setRuns(response.data.runs); setTotalRuns(response.data.total); } catch (err) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", err); setError("Error fetching runs"); } finally { setLoading(false); } }; fetchRuns(); }, [currentPage]); return { runs, loading, error, totalRuns, runsPerPage }; };
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Here’s an updated version of useFetchRuns that will fetch demo data when DEMO_MODE is enabled. This code will check for REACT_APP_DEMO_MODE and switch to a demo endpoint if it's on. When DEMO_MODE is off, it will proceed with fetching data using the usual API endpoint.

javascript
import { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

export const useFetchRuns = (currentPage) => {
  const [runs, setRuns] = useState([]);
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [error, setError] = useState(null);
  const [totalRuns, setTotalRuns] = useState(0);
  const runsPerPage = 5;

  useEffect(() => {
    const fetchRuns = async () => {
      const accessToken = localStorage.getItem("accessToken");
      const demoMode = import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_MODE === "true";

      if (!accessToken && !demoMode) {
        setError("Access token is missing. Please re-authenticate.");
        setLoading(false);
        return;
      }

      try {
        // Set API endpoint based on demo mode
        const endpoint = demoMode
          ? `${import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_API_URL}/api/demo`
          : `${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}?page=${currentPage}`;
        
        // Set headers only if not in demo mode
        const headers = demoMode ? {} : { Authorization: accessToken };

        const response = await axios.get(endpoint, { headers });
        setRuns(response.data.runs || response.data); // Use `response.data` directly if demo mode
        setTotalRuns(response.data.total || response.data.length); // Adjust total based on demo mode data structure
      } catch (err) {
        console.error("Error fetching runs:", err);
        setError("Error fetching runs");
      } finally {
        setLoading(false);
      }
    };

    fetchRuns();
  }, [currentPage]);

  return { runs, loading, error, totalRuns, runsPerPage };
};

Explanation of Changes

  • Demo Mode Check: const demoMode = import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_MODE === "true";

    • Checks if VITE_DEMO_MODE is enabled in the frontend environment. If it’s true, the component switches to using demo data.

  • API Endpoint Selection:

    • If demoMode is true, it fetches from VITE_DEMO_API_URL/api/demo instead of the regular endpoint.

  • Authorization Headers:

    • Skips the authorization header if in demo mode since demo data should not require authentication.

  • Data Handling:

    • In demo mode, response.data may differ in structure, so we directly use it or its array length for totalRuns.

Environment Variables

Ensure the following variables are set in your frontend .env file:

env
VITE_DEMO_MODE=true
VITE_DEMO_API_URL=http://localhost:5000
VITE_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/activities

This update enables seamless switching between demo and live data modes, making it easy to fetch either real or pre-saved demo data depending on the environment setting.

Pasakėte:
Check all my files, did i implement it right HomePage.jsx import { Box, Grid } from "@mui/material"; import polyline from "@mapbox/polyline"; import UserInfo from "../components/user/UserInfo"; import WeeklyStatistics from "../components/run/WeeklyStatistics"; import ShoeStatistics from "../components/shoes/ShoeStatistics"; import LastRunData from "../components/run/LastRunData"; import shoeImage from "../assets/images/nike-structure.png"; import useFetchRunData from "../hooks/useFetchRunData"; export default function HomePage() { const state = useFetchRunData(); if (state.loading) return <div>Loading...</div>; const coordinates = state.lastRun?.summary_polyline ? polyline.decode(state.lastRun.summary_polyline) : []; const mapCenter = coordinates.length ? [coordinates[0][0], coordinates[0][1]] : [0, 0]; const formatDuration = (movingTimeString) => { if (!movingTimeString) return "N/A"; const minutesMatch = movingTimeString.match(/(\d+)\s*minutes/); if (minutesMatch) { const minutes = parseInt(minutesMatch[1], 10); return ${Math.floor(minutes / 60)}h ${minutes % 60}m; } return "N/A"; }; return ( <Box sx={{ p: 3, backgroundColor: "background.default" }}> <UserInfo username="UserName" /> <Grid container spacing={3}> <Grid item xs={12}> <WeeklyStatistics totalKilometersLastWeek={state.totalKilometersLastWeek} totalKilometersCurrentWeek={state.totalKilometersCurrentWeek} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <LastRunData mapCenter={mapCenter} coordinates={coordinates} lastRun={state.lastRun} formatDuration={formatDuration} /> </Grid> </Grid> </Box> ); } UseFetchRuns.js import { useEffect, useState } from "react"; import axios from "axios"; export const useFetchRuns = (currentPage) => { const [runs, setRuns] = useState([]); const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true); const [error, setError] = useState(null); const [totalRuns, setTotalRuns] = useState(0); const runsPerPage = 5; useEffect(() => { const fetchRuns = async () => { const accessToken = localStorage.getItem("accessToken"); const demoMode = import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_MODE === "true"; if (!accessToken && !demoMode) { setError("Access token is missing. Please re-authenticate."); setLoading(false); return; } try { // Set API endpoint based on demo mode const endpoint = demoMode ? ${import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_API_URL}/api/demo : ${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}?page=${currentPage}; // Set headers only if not in demo mode const headers = demoMode ? {} : { Authorization: accessToken }; const response = await axios.get(endpoint, { headers }); setRuns(response.data.runs || response.data); // Use response.data directly if demo mode setTotalRuns(response.data.total || response.data.length); // Adjust total based on demo mode data structure } catch (err) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", err); setError("Error fetching runs"); } finally { setLoading(false); } }; fetchRuns(); }, [currentPage]); return { runs, loading, error, totalRuns, runsPerPage }; }; StravaAuthRoutes.js const express = require("express"); const { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, getDemoData, updateDemoData, } = require("../controllers/stravaAccessController"); const router = express.Router(); router.get("/", getAuthUrl); router.get("/callback", handleAuthCallback); router.get("/demo", getDemoData); router.post("/update-demo", async (req, res) => { try { await updateDemoData(process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN); res.json({ message: "Demo data updated successfully" }); } catch (error) { console.error("Error updating demo data:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error updating demo data" }); } }); module.exports = router; DemoData.js const mongoose = require("mongoose"); const demoDataSchema = new mongoose.Schema({ lastRun: { summary_polyline: String, distance: Number, moving_time: Number, start_date: Date, }, gear: [ { id: String, primary: Boolean, name: String, }, ], totalKilometersLastWeek: Number, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: Number, }); module.exports = mongoose.model("DemoData", demoDataSchema); StravaAccessController.js const DemoData = require("../models/DemoData"); const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); const STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN; // Redirect to the Strava OAuth authorization URL const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; // Handle Strava OAuth callback const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; // Update demo data in the database const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => { const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const demoData = { lastRun: { summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline, distance: data.lastRun.distance, moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time, start_date: data.lastRun.start_date, }, gear: data.gear, totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static or calculated values totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14, }; await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true }); }; // Fetch demo data const getDemoData = async (req, res) => { try { const demoData = await DemoData.findOne({}); if (!demoData) { return res.status(404).json({ message: "Demo data not found" }); } res.json(demoData); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching demo data:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching demo data" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, getDemoData, updateDemoData, };
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Your implementation looks well-structured and correctly aligned with the requirements. Here’s a quick validation of each file with minor recommendations:

1. HomePage.jsx

  • Purpose: Renders the HomePage component with fetched run data, handling DEMO_MODE in the custom hook useFetchRunData.
  • Implementation: Looks correct.
  • Recommendation: No changes needed here.

2. UseFetchRuns.js

  • Purpose: Custom hook to fetch paginated run data, checking DEMO_MODE to switch between the demo and live data endpoints.

  • Implementation: It correctly selects the appropriate API endpoint and handles the presence (or absence) of the access token.

  • Recommendation: Double-check environment variable names to match .env files in both backend and frontend.

    Example:

    javascript
    const demoMode = import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_MODE === "true";

3. StravaAuthRoutes.js

  • Purpose: Defines routes for Strava OAuth and demo data management.
  • Implementation: All routes are correctly implemented. The /update-demo route successfully calls updateDemoData with the STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN.
  • Recommendation: Add comments or documentation to specify that the /update-demo endpoint should be called manually or via a scheduled task if automated demo data updates are required.

4. DemoData.js

  • Purpose: Mongoose schema for storing demo data.
  • Implementation: All fields used in HomePage are correctly defined.
  • Recommendation: No changes needed here.

5. StravaAccessController.js

  • Purpose: Manages Strava OAuth, fetches demo data, and updates demo data in the database.

  • Implementation:

    • updateDemoData fetches the latest run data using the STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN, then saves it with the upsert option.
    • getDemoData retrieves this stored data from MongoDB.

  • Recommendation: Consider error handling for cases where the getLastRunAndGear function doesn’t return the expected data shape, such as missing lastRun or gear. This could improve resilience if Strava data structure changes.

    Example:

    javascript
    const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => {
  try {
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);
    if (!data.lastRun || !data.gear) throw new Error("Incomplete Strava data");

    const demoData = {
      lastRun: {
        summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline,
        distance: data.lastRun.distance,
        moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time,
        start_date: data.lastRun.start_date,
      },
      gear: data.gear,
      totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31,
      totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14,
    };

    await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error updating demo data:", error);
  }
};

General Recommendations

  1. Environment Variables:

    • Ensure that the following variables are correctly set in both the backend and frontend:
      • Backend .env: DEMO_MODE, STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN, MONGODB_URI, CORS_ORIGIN, FRONTEND_URL
      • Frontend .env: VITE_DEMO_MODE, VITE_DEMO_API_URL, VITE_RUNS_API_URL

  2. Testing:

    • Demo Mode: Set VITE_DEMO_MODE=true in the frontend and DEMO_MODE=true in the backend to ensure that demo data is fetched and displayed correctly.
    • Real Data: Turn off demo mode to verify that the live Strava data is fetched.

  3. Automated Demo Data Updates:

    • If regular updates to demo data are required, consider setting up a cron job on the server to call the /update-demo endpoint at intervals (e.g., once a week).

Your setup is solid and should work effectively as a toggleable demo/live environment. Let me know if you need further customization!

Pasakėte:
So i dont get it how my demo data will update based on this setup since i checked my data base and demodatas has 0 documents and no data in it
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

For your demo data to populate in the database, you need to explicitly call the updateDemoData function, which fetches the latest data from Strava and saves it in the database. Here’s how to set it up to ensure demo data is correctly populated:

Step 1: Populate Demo Data

  1. Trigger Demo Data Update Manually:

    • You have a route /update-demo in StravaAuthRoutes.js that calls updateDemoData and saves the fetched Strava data in your database.

    • Call this route once to populate your demo data:

      • Start your backend server.
      • Send a POST request to http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo.

      Using cURL:

      bash
      curl -X POST http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo

      Or, with Postman:

      • Set the method to POST.
      • Enter http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo as the URL.
      • Click Send.

    After calling this endpoint, your database should have one document in DemoData containing your latest Strava data. Check the database to verify.

  2. Automate Demo Data Updates (Optional): If you want to keep demo data updated periodically, set up a cron job or use a task scheduler to call this route at regular intervals (e.g., once a day or week).

Step 2: Verify DEMO_MODE in Frontend and Backend

  1. Ensure DEMO_MODE is enabled:
    • Backend: Set DEMO_MODE=true in the .env file to make the backend serve data from the DemoData collection instead of making real-time API calls.
    • Frontend: Set VITE_DEMO_MODE=true in the frontend .env to make the frontend fetch demo data when the app runs in demo mode.

Summary

  1. Populate Demo Data: Call http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo manually to save demo data.
  2. Enable Demo Mode: Set DEMO_MODE=true in backend and VITE_DEMO_MODE=true in frontend .env files.
  3. View Demo Data: Restart your frontend, and it should now display data from the DemoData collection.

This setup ensures that demo data is served whenever DEMO_MODE is enabled, and you can update the data as needed by calling the /update-demo route.

shpokas@shpokas-Zenbook-UM3402YAR-UM3402YA:~$ curl -X POST http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo {"message":"Error updating demo data"}shpokas@shpokas-Zenbook-UM3402YAR-UM3402YA:~$
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The error message indicates an issue while trying to update demo data. This could happen due to a few reasons, like missing data from Strava or an error in the database connection. Here are steps to debug and identify the root cause:

1. Check Server Logs for More Information

  • After running the curl command, check the console or terminal where your server is running. The console.error("Error updating demo data:", error); statement in updateDemoData should log the full error details.
  • The log should provide more context about the issue, such as a database connection error, an authorization issue with Strava, or an unexpected response format.

2. Verify Strava API Credentials

  • Ensure that STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN is correctly set in your .env file.
  • If the token is missing or invalid, the request to Strava may fail, leading to an error during demo data update.

3. Add Error Handling and Debugging in updateDemoData

To get more insight, you can add additional logging inside updateDemoData. Update the function like this to inspect each step:

javascript
const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => {
  try {
    console.log("Attempting to fetch Strava data with access token:", accessToken);
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);

    if (!data || !data.lastRun || !data.gear) {
      console.error("Error: Incomplete data from Strava API", data);
      throw new Error("Incomplete data from Strava API");
    }

    const demoData = {
      lastRun: {
        summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline,
        distance: data.lastRun.distance,
        moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time,
        start_date: data.lastRun.start_date,
      },
      gear: data.gear,
      totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static or calculated values
      totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14,
    };

    console.log("Saving demo data to the database:", demoData);
    await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true });
    console.log("Demo data updated successfully.");
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error updating demo data:", error);
  }
};

After adding these logs, rerun the curl command and check the server output for each step. Specifically, look for:

  • Access Token Validity: Ensure it’s logging a valid token.
  • Data from Strava API: Confirm that data.lastRun and data.gear contain the expected structure.
  • Database Errors: Look for any issues when saving data to MongoDB.

4. Confirm Database Connection

  • Verify that your MongoDB connection string (MONGODB_URI) is correct and that the database is accessible.
  • Check that MongoDB is running and accessible from your server.

Let Me Know What the Logs Show

The additional logging should help identify whether the problem is with the Strava API response, database connection, or something else. Let me know what the logs reveal so we can troubleshoot further!

/home/shpokas/programming/fullstack-projects/Runtrackr-webapp/backend/routes/stravaAuthRoutes.js:16:5
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The 401 Unauthorized error from Strava indicates that the access token (STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN) is either expired or invalid. Here’s how to resolve it:

Step 1: Verify the Strava Demo Token

  1. Check Token Expiration:

    • Access tokens from Strava expire after six hours. If STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN is expired, it must be refreshed using a refresh token.

  2. Get a New Token:

    • Use your Strava application's client ID, client secret, and refresh token to obtain a new access token.

    You can do this via a direct cURL command or a tool like Postman:

    bash
    curl -X POST https://www.strava.com/oauth/token \
  -d client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID \
  -d client_secret=YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET \
  -d grant_type=refresh_token \
  -d refresh_token=YOUR_REFRESH_TOKEN

    This command will return a new access_token and refresh_token. Update STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN in your .env file with the new access_token.

  3. Store the New Token:

    • Update the .env file with the new STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN.
    • Restart the backend server to apply the updated token.

Step 2: Implement a Token Refresh Mechanism (Optional)

To avoid manually updating the token in the future, you could add a mechanism to refresh the token automatically. Here’s an example function to handle token refresh:

javascript
const axios = require("axios");

const refreshStravaToken = async () => {
  try {
    const response = await axios.post("https://www.strava.com/oauth/token", {
      client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET,
      grant_type: "refresh_token",
      refresh_token: process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN,
    });

    const { access_token, refresh_token } = response.data;
    
    // Update the STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN in-memory and save the new refresh token if necessary
    process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = access_token;
    process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN = refresh_token;

    console.log("Strava token refreshed successfully.");
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error refreshing Strava token:", error);
  }
};

You could call this refreshStravaToken function whenever you detect a 401 Unauthorized response, ensuring the token is updated as needed.

After updating your token, try running the /update-demo endpoint again. This should resolve the 401 error and allow the demo data to be fetched and saved correctly.

Pasakėte:
/update-demo show me local link
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To access the /update-demo endpoint on your local server, use the following link:

plaintext
http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo

Instructions to Test the Endpoint

  1. Start Your Backend Server: Ensure that the server is running on port 5000.
  2. Send a POST Request:
    • Using cURL:
      bash
      curl -X POST http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo
    • Using a Browser or Postman:
      • In a browser, go to http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo (if the server allows GET requests for testing).
      • Alternatively, in Postman:
        • Set the method to POST.
        • Enter http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo as the URL.
        • Click Send.

This should trigger the endpoint to fetch and update the demo data in your database.

„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The 401 Unauthorized error indicates that the access token used to authenticate with Strava (STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN) is either expired or invalid. Here’s a step-by-step guide to resolve this issue:

Step 1: Manually Refresh the Strava Token

To obtain a new access token, use your Strava application's Client ID, Client Secret, and the Refresh Token. The refresh token allows you to request a new access token and refresh token pair from Strava.

You can use the following curl command to request a new access token and refresh token:

bash
curl -X POST https://www.strava.com/oauth/token \
  -d client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID \
  -d client_secret=YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET \
  -d grant_type=refresh_token \
  -d refresh_token=YOUR_REFRESH_TOKEN

Replace:

  • YOUR_CLIENT_ID with your Strava app’s Client ID.
  • YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET with your Strava app’s Client Secret.
  • YOUR_REFRESH_TOKEN with the refresh token associated with STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN.

This request will return a JSON response containing a new access_token and refresh_token.

Step 2: Update .env File

Once you obtain the new access_token, update your .env file with it:

plaintext
STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN=NEW_ACCESS_TOKEN

Additionally, if the refresh_token in the response is new, save it for future token refreshes.

Step 3: Restart Your Server

After updating the .env file, restart your backend server to apply the new token.

bash
node server.js

Step 4: Retest the /update-demo Endpoint

Now that the new access token is set, run the following command to trigger the demo data update:

bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo

This should now succeed and update your demo data.

Optional: Implement Automatic Token Refreshing

If you’d like to avoid this manual step in the future, you can implement automatic token refreshing in your code. Here’s a basic implementation you can add to the updateDemoData function:

  1. Create a refreshStravaToken function to handle token refreshing.

    javascript
    const axios = require("axios");

async function refreshStravaToken() {
  try {
    const response = await axios.post("https://www.strava.com/oauth/token", {
      client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET,
      grant_type: "refresh_token",
      refresh_token: process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN,
    });

    // Update the tokens in memory
    process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = response.data.access_token;
    process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN = response.data.refresh_token;

    console.log("Strava token refreshed successfully.");
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error refreshing Strava token:", error);
    throw error;
  }
}

  2. Call this function within updateDemoData if a 401 error is detected.

Let me know if you run into any other issues!

Pasakėte:
implement optional automatic token refreshing const DemoData = require("../models/DemoData"); const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); const STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN; // Redirect to the Strava OAuth authorization URL const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; // Handle Strava OAuth callback const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; // Update demo data in the database const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => { const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const demoData = { lastRun: { summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline, distance: data.lastRun.distance, moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time, start_date: data.lastRun.start_date, }, gear: data.gear, totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static or calculated values totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14, }; await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true }); }; // Fetch demo data const getDemoData = async (req, res) => { try { const demoData = await DemoData.findOne({}); if (!demoData) { return res.status(404).json({ message: "Demo data not found" }); } res.json(demoData); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching demo data:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching demo data" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, getDemoData, updateDemoData, };
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To add automatic token refreshing in your updateDemoData function, I’ll implement a refreshStravaToken function. This function will check if a 401 Unauthorized error occurs and attempt to refresh the token if needed.

Here’s how you can integrate this functionality:

  1. Add the refreshStravaToken function to handle refreshing the token.
  2. Modify the updateDemoData function to detect a 401 error and call refreshStravaToken as needed.

Here’s the updated code with these changes:

javascript
const DemoData = require("../models/DemoData");
const {
  generateAuthUrl,
  exchangeAuthorizationCode,
  getLastRunAndGear,
} = require("../services/stravaService");
const axios = require("axios");

// Redirect to the Strava OAuth authorization URL
const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => {
  const authUrl = generateAuthUrl();
  res.redirect(authUrl);
};

// Handle Strava OAuth callback
const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => {
  const authorizationCode = req.query.code;

  if (!authorizationCode) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" });
  }

  try {
    const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode);
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);

    const redirectUri = `${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent(
      JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear })
    )}`;
    res.redirect(redirectUri);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during token exchange:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" });
  }
};

// Function to refresh the Strava token
const refreshStravaToken = async () => {
  try {
    const response = await axios.post("https://www.strava.com/oauth/token", {
      client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET,
      grant_type: "refresh_token",
      refresh_token: process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN,
    });

    const { access_token, refresh_token } = response.data;

    // Update the tokens in environment variables
    process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = access_token;
    process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN = refresh_token;

    console.log("Strava token refreshed successfully.");
    return access_token;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error refreshing Strava token:", error);
    throw error;
  }
};

// Update demo data in the database with automatic token refreshing
const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => {
  try {
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);
    const demoData = {
      lastRun: {
        summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline,
        distance: data.lastRun.distance,
        moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time,
        start_date: data.lastRun.start_date,
      },
      gear: data.gear,
      totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static or calculated values
      totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14,
    };

    await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true });
    console.log("Demo data updated successfully.");
  } catch (error) {
    if (error.response && error.response.status === 401) {
      console.log("Access token expired. Attempting to refresh token...");
      const newAccessToken = await refreshStravaToken();
      // Retry updating demo data with the new access token
      await updateDemoData(newAccessToken);
    } else {
      console.error("Error updating demo data:", error);
    }
  }
};

// Fetch demo data
const getDemoData = async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const demoData = await DemoData.findOne({});
    if (!demoData) {
      return res.status(404).json({ message: "Demo data not found" });
    }
    res.json(demoData);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching demo data:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching demo data" });
  }
};

module.exports = {
  getAuthUrl,
  handleAuthCallback,
  getDemoData,
  updateDemoData,
};

Explanation of Changes

  1. refreshStravaToken Function:

    • Sends a POST request to Strava’s token endpoint using the refresh token.
    • If successful, updates STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN and STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN in memory with the new tokens.
    • Returns the new access_token for immediate use.

  2. Automatic Refresh in updateDemoData:

    • If a 401 Unauthorized error is detected, it calls refreshStravaToken to obtain a new token.
    • After refreshing the token, it retries updateDemoData with the new access token.

This implementation ensures that your Strava token is automatically refreshed whenever it expires, allowing the demo data to update successfully without manual intervention. Let me know if you have any questions!

Pasakėte:
also here is my .env of backend STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=138288 STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=50ac4dfa13bc7ae1919c9ca714e2ddb8df576b29 ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET=bfe7d87bf90850d02019036192aead6866352be9 REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET=e7955348cf80d466f20c1f3ed62b55b94351e2b5 STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN=513e3722999dff6d3f9851e03a103ae06bb46f26 DEMO_MODE=true STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173 CORS_ORIGIN=http://localhost:5173 MONGODB_URI=mongodb://localhost:27017/runtrackr STRAVA_AUTH_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize STRAVA_TOKEN_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/token STRAVA_ACTIVITIES_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities STRAVA_ATHLETE_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete STRAVA_GEAR_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear PORT=5000
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Your .env file contains the necessary variables for Strava integration, MongoDB, and your server configuration. Here’s a summary of its contents along with additional notes on required updates:

Key Environment Variables and Usage

  • Strava API Credentials:

    • STRAVA_CLIENT_ID and STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET: Used to authenticate with Strava.
    • STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN: Initially set for demo data requests but should be refreshed automatically as per the new code.

  • Authorization and Callback URLs:

    • STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI: Ensures Strava redirects users back to your server after authorization.
    • STRAVA_AUTH_URL, STRAVA_TOKEN_URL, STRAVA_ACTIVITIES_URL, STRAVA_ATHLETE_URL, STRAVA_GEAR_URL: URLs for Strava’s OAuth and API requests.

  • Server and Database Settings:

    • FRONTEND_URL: Specifies the origin for your frontend, essential for redirect and CORS configuration.
    • CORS_ORIGIN: Allows frontend requests from http://localhost:5173.
    • MONGODB_URI: Connects to the MongoDB database at localhost:27017/runtrackr.
    • PORT: Defines the server’s listening port (5000).

Updates Needed in .env for Token Refresh

To support automatic token refreshing, add a refresh token variable that can be updated as needed:

  1. Add STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN:

    • Add STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN to your .env file. If you already have the current refresh token from Strava, set it here:
    env
    STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=YOUR_CURRENT_REFRESH_TOKEN
    • If the current refresh token is unknown, you may need to go through the initial OAuth process to obtain it.

  2. Configure refreshStravaToken to Use the Variable:

    • When refreshStravaToken fetches a new access and refresh token, the refresh token in STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN should be updated as follows:
      javascript
      process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = access_token;
process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN = refresh_token;

Final .env Example with STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN

Here’s what your .env file would look like with the addition of STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN:

env
STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=138288
STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=50ac4dfa13bc7ae1919c9ca714e2ddb8df576b29
ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET=bfe7d87bf90850d02019036192aead6866352be9
REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET=e7955348cf80d466f20c1f3ed62b55b94351e2b5
STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN=513e3722999dff6d3f9851e03a103ae06bb46f26
STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=YOUR_CURRENT_REFRESH_TOKEN
DEMO_MODE=true
STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback
FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173
CORS_ORIGIN=http://localhost:5173
MONGODB_URI=mongodb://localhost:27017/runtrackr
STRAVA_AUTH_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize
STRAVA_TOKEN_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/token
STRAVA_ACTIVITIES_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities
STRAVA_ATHLETE_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete
STRAVA_GEAR_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear
PORT=5000

With this setup, the STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN will allow your server to refresh the access token automatically when it expires, maintaining access to Strava's API for demo data updates.
