„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The error you're seeing suggests that the 401 Unauthorized response from Strava was not resolved by the automatic refresh process, likely because either the refresh token is invalid or the refreshStravaToken function didn’t execute as expected.

To fix this, let’s verify a few key points and enhance error handling to ensure the refresh token logic is working as intended.

Step 1: Ensure STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN is Set Correctly in .env

Double-check that your .env file includes a valid STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN like so:

plaintext
STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=YOUR_REFRESH_TOKEN

Step 2: Confirm refreshStravaToken Logic

Let’s add additional logging in the refreshStravaToken function to verify that it’s attempting to refresh the token when 401 errors occur and actually updating STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN.

Here’s an enhanced version of refreshStravaToken and updateDemoData with added logging and error handling:

javascript
const DemoData = require("../models/DemoData");
const axios = require("axios");
const {
  generateAuthUrl,
  exchangeAuthorizationCode,
  getLastRunAndGear,
} = require("../services/stravaService");

// Function to refresh the Strava token
const refreshStravaToken = async () => {
  console.log("Attempting to refresh Strava token...");
  try {
    const response = await axios.post(process.env.STRAVA_TOKEN_URL, {
      client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET,
      grant_type: "refresh_token",
      refresh_token: process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN,
    });

    const { access_token, refresh_token } = response.data;

    // Update the tokens in environment variables
    process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = access_token;
    process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN = refresh_token;

    console.log("Strava token refreshed successfully.");
    return access_token;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error refreshing Strava token:", error.response?.data || error.message);
    throw error;
  }
};

// Update demo data in the database with automatic token refreshing
const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => {
  try {
    console.log("Attempting to fetch demo data with access token:", accessToken);
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);
    const demoData = {
      lastRun: {
        summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline,
        distance: data.lastRun.distance,
        moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time,
        start_date: data.lastRun.start_date,
      },
      gear: data.gear,
      totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static or calculated values
      totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14,
    };

    await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true });
    console.log("Demo data updated successfully.");
  } catch (error) {
    if (error.response && error.response.status === 401) {
      console.log("Access token expired. Attempting to refresh token...");
      try {
        const newAccessToken = await refreshStravaToken();
        // Retry updating demo data with the new access token
        await updateDemoData(newAccessToken);
      } catch (refreshError) {
        console.error("Failed to refresh token or update demo data after refresh:", refreshError.message);
      }
    } else {
      console.error("Error updating demo data:", error.message);
    }
  }
};

// Exporting functions
module.exports = {
  getAuthUrl,
  handleAuthCallback,
  getDemoData,
  updateDemoData,
};

Step 3: Restart the Server and Test the Endpoint

  1. Restart Your Backend Server:

    bash
    node server.js

  2. Trigger the /update-demo Endpoint: Use the following command to test if the token refresh logic is working:

    bash
    curl -X POST http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo

Explanation of Changes

  1. Detailed Logging:

    • Logs have been added to confirm when the refreshStravaToken function is called and whether it successfully retrieves a new token.
    • The retry mechanism in updateDemoData now logs each step, including failure messages if the refresh attempt doesn’t work.

  2. Error Handling:

    • The catch block in updateDemoData retries the data update if it detects a 401 Unauthorized response, indicating an expired token.

Important Note

If you still receive the 401 error after these changes, double-check that:

  • The refresh token in STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN is valid and hasn’t expired.
  • The STRAVA_TOKEN_URL is correct (https://www.strava.com/oauth/token).

This should help diagnose and resolve any remaining issues with automatic token refreshing.

Pasakėte:
debug using ,my code here is my .env file STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=138288 STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=50ac4dfa13bc7ae1919c9ca714e2ddb8df576b29 ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET=bfe7d87bf90850d02019036192aead6866352be9 REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET=e7955348cf80d466f20c1f3ed62b55b94351e2b5 STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN=513e3722999dff6d3f9851e03a103ae06bb46f26 DEMO_MODE=true STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=e7955348cf80d466f20c1f3ed62b55b94351e2b5 STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173 CORS_ORIGIN=http://localhost:5173 MONGODB_URI=mongodb://localhost:27017/runtrackr STRAVA_AUTH_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize STRAVA_TOKEN_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/token STRAVA_ACTIVITIES_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities STRAVA_ATHLETE_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete STRAVA_GEAR_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear PORT=5000 Here is my DemoData model const mongoose = require("mongoose"); const demoDataSchema = new mongoose.Schema({ lastRun: { summary_polyline: String, distance: Number, moving_time: Number, start_date: Date, }, gear: [ { id: String, primary: Boolean, name: String, }, ], totalKilometersLastWeek: Number, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: Number, }); module.exports = mongoose.model("DemoData", demoDataSchema); here is my stravaAccessController const DemoData = require("../models/DemoData"); const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); const axios = require("axios"); // Redirect to the Strava OAuth authorization URL const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; // Handle Strava OAuth callback const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; // Function to refresh the Strava token const refreshStravaToken = async () => { try { const response = await axios.post("https://www.strava.com/oauth/token", { client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID, client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET, grant_type: "refresh_token", refresh_token: process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN, }); const { access_token, refresh_token } = response.data; // Update the tokens in environment variables process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = access_token; process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN = refresh_token; console.log("Strava token refreshed successfully."); return access_token; } catch (error) { console.error("Error refreshing Strava token:", error); throw error; } }; // Update demo data in the database with automatic token refreshing const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => { try { const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const demoData = { lastRun: { summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline, distance: data.lastRun.distance, moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time, start_date: data.lastRun.start_date, }, gear: data.gear, totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static or calculated values totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14, }; await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true }); console.log("Demo data updated successfully."); } catch (error) { if (error.response && error.response.status === 401) { console.log("Access token expired. Attempting to refresh token..."); const newAccessToken = await refreshStravaToken(); // Retry updating demo data with the new access token await updateDemoData(newAccessToken); } else { console.error("Error updating demo data:", error); } } }; // Fetch demo data const getDemoData = async (req, res) => { try { const demoData = await DemoData.findOne({}); if (!demoData) { return res.status(404).json({ message: "Demo data not found" }); } res.json(demoData); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching demo data:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching demo data" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, getDemoData, updateDemoData, }; HEre is my stravaAuthROutes const express = require("express"); const { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, getDemoData, updateDemoData, } = require("../controllers/stravaAccessController"); const router = express.Router(); router.get("/", getAuthUrl); router.get("/callback", handleAuthCallback); router.get("/demo", getDemoData); router.post("/update-demo", async (req, res) => { try { await updateDemoData(process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN); res.json({ message: "Demo data updated successfully" }); } catch (error) { console.error("Error updating demo data:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error updating demo data" }); } }); module.exports = router;
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

From reviewing your provided code and .env file, everything seems generally well-configured for refreshing the token and updating the demo data. However, given that the 401 Unauthorized error persists, let's add more detailed debugging to identify exactly where things might be going wrong.

Here’s a step-by-step debugging approach and some code modifications to help trace the exact issue:

Step 1: Add Debugging Logs in refreshStravaToken and updateDemoData

  1. Add Detailed Logs to refreshStravaToken: This will confirm if the refresh token request is successfully sent and what data is returned.

  2. Add Detailed Logs to updateDemoData: These logs will track the access token used and the outcome of fetching data.

Update your refreshStravaToken and updateDemoData functions with these logs:

javascript
// Function to refresh the Strava token
const refreshStravaToken = async () => {
  console.log("Attempting to refresh Strava token with current refresh token:", process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN);
  try {
    const response = await axios.post(process.env.STRAVA_TOKEN_URL, {
      client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET,
      grant_type: "refresh_token",
      refresh_token: process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN,
    });

    const { access_token, refresh_token } = response.data;

    // Update the tokens in environment variables
    process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = access_token;
    process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN = refresh_token;

    console.log("Strava token refreshed successfully. New access token:", access_token);
    console.log("Updated refresh token:", refresh_token);

    return access_token;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error refreshing Strava token:", error.response?.data || error.message);
    throw error;
  }
};

// Update demo data in the database with automatic token refreshing
const updateDemoData = async (accessToken) => {
  console.log("Using access token to update demo data:", accessToken);
  try {
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);
    console.log("Data fetched from Strava:", data);

    const demoData = {
      lastRun: {
        summary_polyline: data.lastRun.summary_polyline,
        distance: data.lastRun.distance,
        moving_time: data.lastRun.moving_time,
        start_date: data.lastRun.start_date,
      },
      gear: data.gear,
      totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, // Static or calculated values
      totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14,
    };

    await DemoData.findOneAndUpdate({}, demoData, { upsert: true });
    console.log("Demo data updated successfully.");
  } catch (error) {
    if (error.response && error.response.status === 401) {
      console.log("Access token expired. Attempting to refresh token...");
      try {
        const newAccessToken = await refreshStravaToken();
        console.log("Retrying update with new access token:", newAccessToken);
        await updateDemoData(newAccessToken);
      } catch (refreshError) {
        console.error("Failed to refresh token or update demo data after refresh:", refreshError.message);
      }
    } else {
      console.error("Error updating demo data:", error.response?.data || error.message);
    }
  }
};

Step 2: Run the Server and Monitor Output

  1. Restart Your Server:

    bash
    node server.js

  2. Trigger the /update-demo Endpoint: Send a request to /update-demo:

    bash
    curl -X POST http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo

  3. Observe Console Logs: Check the following in the logs:

    • Whether the refreshStravaToken function is being called when the 401 error occurs.
    • The values returned by the refresh token request (access_token and refresh_token).
    • Whether updateDemoData retries with the new access token after refreshing.

Step 3: Verify .env Token Update (Optional)

Since the environment variables are updated in memory (not in the .env file directly), you may want to manually update STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN and STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN in your .env file with the latest values obtained from the logs.

Step 4: Test the Frontend Connection

After successful updates in the backend, test the frontend by making requests to http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/demo to confirm that demo data is successfully returned.

This process should help identify if there are any issues in the refresh token flow and confirm that the correct data is being fetched from Strava and stored in your database. Let me know what specific logs you observe, especially any errors, so I can provide further assistance if needed.

„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The console output confirms that the 401 error is occurring when the server tries to fetch data using an expired STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN. Although the code attempts to fetch a new access token, it’s possible the refresh process isn’t working as expected due to an outdated or invalid STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN in your .env file.

Here’s a step-by-step approach to resolving the issue:

Step 1: Confirm Current Refresh Token Validity

  1. Re-authenticate with Strava to obtain a new access_token and refresh_token:

    • Go through the OAuth process to get fresh tokens directly from Strava.
    • Update the .env file with these new values:
      plaintext
      STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN=your_new_access_token
STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=your_new_refresh_token

  2. Restart the Server after updating the .env file:

    bash
    node server.js

  3. Test the /update-demo Endpoint: Run the curl command again to verify if the update works:

    bash
    curl -X POST http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/update-demo

Step 2: Ensure Tokens Persist Between Restarts (Optional)

Currently, the updated access_token and refresh_token from refreshStravaToken are only available in memory, meaning any server restart will revert to the .env values. If you'd like to save the refreshed tokens persistently:

  1. Write the Refreshed Tokens Back to .env (Optional): Modify refreshStravaToken to update the .env file each time a new token is fetched:
    javascript
    const fs = require("fs");

const refreshStravaToken = async () => {
  console.log("Attempting to refresh Strava token...");
  try {
    const response = await axios.post(process.env.STRAVA_TOKEN_URL, {
      client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET,
      grant_type: "refresh_token",
      refresh_token: process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN,
    });

    const { access_token, refresh_token } = response.data;

    process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = access_token;
    process.env.STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN = refresh_token;

    console.log("Strava token refreshed successfully.");

    // Update .env file
    fs.writeFileSync(
      ".env",
      `STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN=${access_token}\nSTRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=${refresh_token}\n`,
      { flag: "a" } // append to existing .env file
    );

    return access_token;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error refreshing Strava token:", error.response?.data || error.message);
    throw error;
  }
};

This will allow the updated tokens to persist in your .env file even if the server restarts.

After these changes, re-test the endpoint to confirm the issue has been resolved. Let me know if the refresh is now functioning correctly or if there are any further errors.

Pasakėte:
now my allRuns.jsx page displays Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 (Not Found)Understand this errorAI :5000/api/activities?page=1:1 Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 (Not Found)Understand this errorAI hook.js:608 Error fetching runs: AxiosError overrideMethod @ hook.js:608 Show 1 more frame Show lessUnderstand this errorAI hook.js:608 Error fetching runs: AxiosError
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The 404 Not Found error for :5000/api/activities?page=1 suggests that your backend is not recognizing the route /api/activities. Here’s how to troubleshoot and fix it:

Step 1: Verify the Route in indexRoutes.js or Equivalent Routing File

Check that /api/activities is defined in your routing configuration. If you have a file like indexRoutes.js or similar, ensure it includes a route for /activities.

Example:

javascript
const express = require("express");
const router = express.Router();
const activitiesController = require("../controllers/activitiesController"); // Adjust path if needed

router.get("/activities", activitiesController.getActivities);

module.exports = router;

Step 2: Ensure indexRoutes.js Is Properly Mounted in server.js

In server.js, make sure the routes are correctly registered to be accessible under /api:

javascript
const activitiesRoutes = require("./routes/indexRoutes"); // or activitiesRoutes.js
app.use("/api", activitiesRoutes);

Step 3: Verify the Activities Controller and Method

In your activitiesController (or equivalent), ensure there’s a getActivities function handling requests for /api/activities:

javascript
// controllers/activitiesController.js
exports.getActivities = async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const page = req.query.page || 1;
    const activities = await ActivityModel.find() // Replace `ActivityModel` with the actual model you're using
      .limit(10) // Example: limit results per page
      .skip((page - 1) * 10);
    res.json({ activities });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching activities:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching activities" });
  }
};

Step 4: Restart the Server

After making sure everything is set up correctly, restart your server to apply changes:

bash
node server.js

Step 5: Test the Endpoint Manually

To confirm the endpoint is working, you can use a tool like curl or Postman:

bash
curl http://localhost:5000/api/activities?page=1

Additional Notes

  • If axios is used on the frontend to fetch data, ensure axios is making the request to the correct base URL (like http://localhost:5000/api/activities).
  • Double-check any environment variables for the backend API URL, particularly if you’re using relative paths on the frontend.

These steps should help fix the 404 error for your /api/activities route.

„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The 404 Not Found error in useFetchRuns.js for the GET http://localhost:5000/api/activities?page=1 request suggests that the backend route /api/activities doesn’t exist or isn’t set up correctly. Here’s how to resolve this issue:

Steps to Debug and Fix

  1. Check Route Setup in the Backend

    Ensure that there’s a route handler for /activities in your backend.

    In your backend routing file (e.g., indexRoutes.js or similar), verify that /activities is defined. It should look something like this:

    javascript
    const express = require("express");
const router = express.Router();
const activitiesController = require("../controllers/activitiesController");

router.get("/activities", activitiesController.getActivities);

module.exports = router;
    • Ensure the getActivities method in activitiesController is correctly set up to handle requests and return data for activities.

  2. Mount Routes Correctly in server.js

    In server.js, verify that your routes are properly mounted. For instance:

    javascript
    const activitiesRoutes = require("./routes/indexRoutes"); // or routes for activities specifically
app.use("/api", activitiesRoutes);

    This setup will make the /api/activities route available for the frontend.

  3. Verify activitiesController Function

    In the activitiesController.js (or equivalent), ensure that the getActivities function exists and is correctly implemented to retrieve and return data:

    javascript
    // controllers/activitiesController.js
exports.getActivities = async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const page = parseInt(req.query.page) || 1;
    const limit = 10;
    const activities = await ActivityModel.find() // Adjust model name
      .limit(limit)
      .skip((page - 1) * limit);

    res.json({ activities });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching activities:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching activities" });
  }
};
    • Adjust ActivityModel to your actual MongoDB model if needed.
    • The limit and skip methods help implement pagination.

  4. Restart the Server

    After verifying or making changes, restart your server:

    bash
    node server.js

  5. Test the Endpoint Directly

    Use curl or Postman to test the endpoint manually:

    bash
    curl http://localhost:5000/api/activities?page=1

    This should return a JSON response with activity data if everything is correctly set up.

  6. Check Frontend URL Configuration

    Verify that the frontend configuration (useFetchRuns.js) is using the correct URL:

    javascript
    const response = await axios.get(`${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}/activities?page=${currentPage}`);

    Ensure VITE_RUNS_API_URL is set to http://localhost:5000/api in your frontend .env file.

Additional Notes

  • Verify Models: Ensure that the activity data model in MongoDB is correct and that there is data to retrieve.
  • Debugging Logs: If the error persists, add console.log statements in activitiesController and server.js to see where the request might be failing.

Following these steps should help resolve the 404 error on the /activities endpoint. Let me know if further assistance is needed!

Please re-authenticate."); setLoading(false); return; } try { const response = await axios.get( ${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}?page=${currentPage}, { headers: { Authorization: accessToken } } ); setRuns(response.data.runs); setTotalRuns(response.data.total); } catch (err) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", err); setError("Error fetching runs"); } finally { setLoading(false); } }; fetchRuns(); }, [currentPage]); return { runs, loading, error, totalRuns, runsPerPage }; };
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

In useFetchRuns.js, the code currently uses ${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}?page=${currentPage}, which may not point directly to /api/activities. Here’s how to adjust it to make sure it targets the correct endpoint:

Suggested Code Update

Replace this line in useFetchRuns.js:

javascript
const response = await axios.get(
  `${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}?page=${currentPage}`,
  { headers: { Authorization: accessToken } }
);

with this updated line that explicitly targets /activities:

javascript
const response = await axios.get(
  `${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}/activities?page=${currentPage}`,
  { headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}` } }
);

Explanation of Changes

  1. URL Path Update:

    • ${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}/activities?page=${currentPage}: This ensures the request goes to /api/activities instead of directly to the root API URL.

  2. Authorization Header Format:

    • Authorization: \Bearer ${accessToken}`: This format (Bearer <token>`) is more standard for authorization headers and may be required by the backend.

  3. Environment Variable Check:

    • Make sure VITE_RUNS_API_URL in your frontend .env file is set correctly to http://localhost:5000/api.

Example Frontend .env File

Your .env file in the frontend directory should look like this:

plaintext
VITE_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api

Testing

After making these changes:

  1. Restart your frontend server to apply the environment variable changes.
  2. Confirm if the data loads correctly on the /activities route.

This adjustment should resolve the 404 Not Found error if the backend /api/activities endpoint is set up correctly.

„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The 404 Not Found error indicates that the frontend is attempting to access the /api/activities endpoint on the backend, but this route either does not exist or is incorrectly configured. Here’s how to troubleshoot and resolve the issue:

Steps to Resolve

  1. Verify the Backend Route Setup Ensure that you have defined a route for /activities in your backend that matches the expected path in useFetchRuns.js.

    For example, if your backend route file (e.g., indexRoutes.js) should contain a route definition like this:

    javascript
    const express = require("express");
const router = express.Router();
const activitiesController = require("../controllers/activitiesController");

router.get("/activities", activitiesController.getActivities);

module.exports = router;

  2. Check the Route Mounting in server.js Verify that you have mounted this route correctly in server.js. For instance:

    javascript
    const activitiesRoutes = require("./routes/indexRoutes"); // or wherever you define your activity routes
app.use("/api", activitiesRoutes);

    This setup will make the /api/activities route accessible to the frontend.

  3. Ensure activitiesController is Correctly Implemented In your activitiesController.js, the getActivities function should look something like this:

    javascript
    // controllers/activitiesController.js
exports.getActivities = async (req, res) => {
  try {
    const page = parseInt(req.query.page) || 1;
    const limit = 10; // Adjust as needed
    const activities = await ActivityModel.find() // Replace with your actual model
      .limit(limit)
      .skip((page - 1) * limit);

    res.json({ runs: activities, total: activities.length });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching activities:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching activities" });
  }
};

    Replace ActivityModel with the actual name of your Mongoose model if it’s different.

  4. Check the URL in useFetchRuns.js

    Make sure that the URL matches the path configured in the backend:

    javascript
    const response = await axios.get(
  `${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}/activities?page=${currentPage}`,
  { headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}` } }
);

  5. Verify .env Settings for VITE_RUNS_API_URL

    In the frontend .env file, ensure that VITE_RUNS_API_URL is set to http://localhost:5000/api.

    plaintext
    VITE_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api

  6. Restart the Backend and Frontend Servers

    After making these adjustments, restart both servers to ensure the new configurations are applied.

Testing the API Endpoint

You can test the endpoint directly using a tool like curl or Postman:

bash
curl http://localhost:5000/api/activities?page=1

If it returns data, then the route is working correctly. If not, check your backend logs for additional error details.

By following these steps, the frontend useFetchRuns hook should successfully retrieve data from the backend without a 404 error.

here is my useFetchRUns.js import { useEffect, useState } from "react"; import axios from "axios"; export const useFetchRuns = (currentPage) => { const [runs, setRuns] = useState([]); const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true); const [error, setError] = useState(null); const [totalRuns, setTotalRuns] = useState(0); const runsPerPage = 5; useEffect(() => { const fetchRuns = async () => { const accessToken = localStorage.getItem("accessToken"); if (!accessToken) { setError("Access token is missing. Please re-authenticate."); setLoading(false); return; } try { const response = await axios.get( ${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}/activities?page=${currentPage}, { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} } } ); setRuns(response.data.runs); setTotalRuns(response.data.total); } catch (err) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", err); setError("Error fetching runs"); } finally { setLoading(false); } }; fetchRuns(); }, [currentPage]); return { runs, loading, error, totalRuns, runsPerPage }; }; here is my .env REACT_APP_USE_DEMO_MODE=true REACT_APP_STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN=2623039d8a4f21abb1a755d518a0adf85410d032 VITE_DEMO_RUNS_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/demo-runs VITE_RUNS_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/runs VITE_STRAVA_AUTH_URL=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava VITE_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/runs VITE_SHOES_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/shoes VITE_DEMO_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/demo-all-runs VITE_DEMO_SHOES_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/demo-shoes VITE_DEMO_MODE=true VITE_DEMO_API_URL=http://localhost:5000 VITE_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

It seems there are some inconsistencies in the environment variables in your .env file, particularly multiple definitions of VITE_RUNS_API_URL. Here’s a streamlined approach to make sure your useFetchRuns.js can access the correct URL and avoid the 404 Not Found issue:

  1. Remove Duplicate Environment Variables
    In your .env file, there’s a duplicate declaration for VITE_RUNS_API_URL. Remove one of these and ensure consistency throughout:

    plaintext
    VITE_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/runs

  2. Update useFetchRuns.js to Support Demo Mode
    Modify useFetchRuns.js to check for demo mode and switch between VITE_DEMO_RUNS_API_URL and VITE_RUNS_API_URL accordingly:

    javascript
    import { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

export const useFetchRuns = (currentPage) => {
  const [runs, setRuns] = useState([]);
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [error, setError] = useState(null);
  const [totalRuns, setTotalRuns] = useState(0);
  const runsPerPage = 5;

  const isDemoMode = import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_MODE === "true";
  const runsApiUrl = isDemoMode
    ? import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_RUNS_API_URL
    : import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL;

  useEffect(() => {
    const fetchRuns = async () => {
      const accessToken = localStorage.getItem("accessToken");

      if (!accessToken && !isDemoMode) {
        setError("Access token is missing. Please re-authenticate.");
        setLoading(false);
        return;
      }

      try {
        const response = await axios.get(
          `${runsApiUrl}?page=${currentPage}`,
          {
            headers: isDemoMode ? {} : { Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}` },
          }
        );
        setRuns(response.data.runs || response.data);
        setTotalRuns(response.data.total || response.data.length);
      } catch (err) {
        console.error("Error fetching runs:", err);
        setError("Error fetching runs");
      } finally {
        setLoading(false);
      }
    };

    fetchRuns();
  }, [currentPage]);

  return { runs, loading, error, totalRuns, runsPerPage };
};

  3. Verify Backend Route Paths

    Ensure that your backend has the following routes for both regular and demo data:

    javascript
    // In routes file, e.g., `indexRoutes.js` or similar
const express = require("express");
const router = express.Router();
const demoController = require("../controllers/demoController"); // If you have a controller for demo
const activitiesController = require("../controllers/activitiesController");

// Regular API route
router.get("/runs", activitiesController.getActivities);

// Demo mode route
router.get("/demo-all-runs", demoController.getDemoActivities); // Ensure this is defined in your controller

module.exports = router;

  4. Restart Backend and Frontend Servers

    After making these changes, restart both servers to apply the updates.

With these adjustments, the useFetchRuns.js file will correctly toggle between regular and demo data based on the VITE_DEMO_MODE flag, and both URLs will point to the appropriate endpoints.

„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To fully remove demo mode from your project, we’ll need to modify or delete any files and code blocks that reference demo-related functionality. Please provide the following files where demo mode is implemented or referenced:

  1. Environment Variables

    • .env: This file likely contains environment variables related to demo mode (e.g., VITE_DEMO_MODE, VITE_DEMO_RUNS_API_URL), which will need to be removed.

  2. Frontend Files

    • useFetchRuns.js: Since demo mode may affect how this hook fetches data, we’ll need this file to remove any demo-related logic.
    • Any other hook or component files where demo mode toggling is implemented (e.g., useFetchShoes.js if it exists).
    • App.jsx or index.js: If demo mode is toggled at a higher level, these files might include demo-specific routing or conditionals.

  3. Backend Files

    • server.js or app.js: If demo mode conditionals are in the main server file, we’ll need this to ensure clean removal.
    • Backend routes (e.g., routes/indexRoutes.js or similar): Any route files that include demo mode routes such as /demo-runs, /demo-shoes, etc.
    • Controllers for Demo Data (if you have one, like demoController.js): This will need to be removed entirely.

  4. Database Models

    • Any models related specifically to demo data (e.g., DemoData.js) should also be removed if they’re only for demo purposes.

Once I have these files, I can guide you through removing all demo mode references to make sure your project is clean and focused on live data only.

Pasakėte:
Remove safelly demo mode from Homepage.jsx import { Box, Grid } from "@mui/material"; import polyline from "@mapbox/polyline"; import UserInfo from "../components/user/UserInfo"; import WeeklyStatistics from "../components/run/WeeklyStatistics"; import ShoeStatistics from "../components/shoes/ShoeStatistics"; import LastRunData from "../components/run/LastRunData"; import shoeImage from "../assets/images/nike-structure.png"; import useFetchRunData from "../hooks/useFetchRunData"; export default function HomePage() { const state = useFetchRunData(); if (state.loading) return <div>Loading...</div>; const coordinates = state.lastRun?.summary_polyline ? polyline.decode(state.lastRun.summary_polyline) : []; const mapCenter = coordinates.length ? [coordinates[0][0], coordinates[0][1]] : [0, 0]; const formatDuration = (movingTimeString) => { if (!movingTimeString) return "N/A"; const minutesMatch = movingTimeString.match(/(\d+)\s*minutes/); if (minutesMatch) { const minutes = parseInt(minutesMatch[1], 10); return ${Math.floor(minutes / 60)}h ${minutes % 60}m; } return "N/A"; }; return ( <Box sx={{ p: 3, backgroundColor: "background.default" }}> <UserInfo username="UserName" /> <Grid container spacing={3}> <Grid item xs={12}> <WeeklyStatistics totalKilometersLastWeek={state.totalKilometersLastWeek} totalKilometersCurrentWeek={state.totalKilometersCurrentWeek} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <LastRunData mapCenter={mapCenter} coordinates={coordinates} lastRun={state.lastRun} formatDuration={formatDuration} /> </Grid> </Grid> </Box> ); }
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To safely remove demo mode from HomePage.jsx, ensure that any demo-related data handling and conditional logic is removed, focusing only on live data from your main data sources. Based on your provided code, it appears there might be additional demo logic in the useFetchRunData hook. Here’s the cleaned-up HomePage.jsx without any demo mode checks or data.

Updated HomePage.jsx

javascript
import { Box, Grid } from "@mui/material";
import polyline from "@mapbox/polyline";
import UserInfo from "../components/user/UserInfo";
import WeeklyStatistics from "../components/run/WeeklyStatistics";
import ShoeStatistics from "../components/shoes/ShoeStatistics";
import LastRunData from "../components/run/LastRunData";
import shoeImage from "../assets/images/nike-structure.png";
import useFetchRunData from "../hooks/useFetchRunData";

export default function HomePage() {
  const state = useFetchRunData();

  if (state.loading) return <div>Loading...</div>;

  const coordinates = state.lastRun?.summary_polyline
    ? polyline.decode(state.lastRun.summary_polyline)
    : [];
  const mapCenter = coordinates.length
    ? [coordinates[0][0], coordinates[0][1]]
    : [0, 0];

  const formatDuration = (movingTimeString) => {
    if (!movingTimeString) return "N/A";
    const minutesMatch = movingTimeString.match(/(\d+)\s*minutes/);
    if (minutesMatch) {
      const minutes = parseInt(minutesMatch[1], 10);
      return `${Math.floor(minutes / 60)}h ${minutes % 60}m`;
    }
    return "N/A";
  };

  return (
    <Box sx={{ p: 3, backgroundColor: "background.default" }}>
      <UserInfo username="UserName" />
      <Grid container spacing={3}>
        <Grid item xs={12}>
          <WeeklyStatistics
            totalKilometersLastWeek={state.totalKilometersLastWeek}
            totalKilometersCurrentWeek={state.totalKilometersCurrentWeek}
          />
        </Grid>
        <Grid item xs={12} md={6}>
          <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} />
        </Grid>
        <Grid item xs={12} md={6}>
          <LastRunData
            mapCenter={mapCenter}
            coordinates={coordinates}
            lastRun={state.lastRun}
            formatDuration={formatDuration}
          />
        </Grid>
      </Grid>
    </Box>
  );
}

Additional Steps:

  1. Update useFetchRunData Hook: Make sure useFetchRunData is fetching only live data. Remove any demo-related toggling or logic within this hook.
  2. Environment Variables: Remove any demo-related environment variables from .env files and update your configuration files accordingly.
  3. Delete Unused Files: Remove any files specifically used for demo data, such as demo routes or controllers in the backend.

This ensures that your HomePage.jsx relies solely on the main data source, making your app clean and demo-free. Let me know if you need further help with specific files!

Pasakėte:
remove demo from useFetchRUnData import { useState, useEffect } from "react"; import axios from "axios"; export default function useFetchRunData() { const [state, setState] = useState({ shoeStats: null, lastRun: null, totalKilometersLastWeek: 0, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 0, loading: true, }); const isDemoMode = false; // Demo mode on/off useEffect(() => { const fetchData = async () => { try { const url = isDemoMode ? import.meta.env.VITE_DEMO_RUNS_URL : import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_URL; if (isDemoMode) { const response = await axios.get(url); setState({ shoeStats: response.data.gear, lastRun: { ...response.data.lastRun, distance: parseFloat(response.data.lastRun.distance), }, totalKilometersLastWeek: response.data.totalKilometersLastWeek, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: response.data.totalKilometersCurrentWeek, loading: false, }); } else { const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search); const data = urlParams.get("data"); if (data) { const parsedData = JSON.parse(decodeURIComponent(data)); const accessToken = parsedData.accessToken; if (accessToken) { localStorage.setItem("accessToken", accessToken); } const response = await axios.get(url, { headers: { Authorization: accessToken }, }); setState({ shoeStats: parsedData.gear, lastRun: { ...parsedData.lastRun, distance: parseFloat(parsedData.lastRun.distance), }, totalKilometersLastWeek: response.data.totalKilometersLastWeek, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: response.data.totalKilometersCurrentWeek, loading: false, }); } else { window.location.href = import.meta.env.VITE_STRAVA_AUTH_URL; } } } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching run data:", error); setState((prevState) => ({ ...prevState, loading: false })); } }; fetchData(); }, [isDemoMode]); return state; }
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To fully remove demo mode from useFetchRunData, we can delete all references to isDemoMode, VITE_DEMO_RUNS_URL, and conditional logic used to handle demo data. This simplifies the code to only handle live data with the standard URL and authentication.

Updated useFetchRunData

javascript
import { useState, useEffect } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

export default function useFetchRunData() {
  const [state, setState] = useState({
    shoeStats: null,
    lastRun: null,
    totalKilometersLastWeek: 0,
    totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 0,
    loading: true,
  });

  useEffect(() => {
    const fetchData = async () => {
      try {
        const url = import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_URL;
        const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
        const data = urlParams.get("data");

        if (data) {
          const parsedData = JSON.parse(decodeURIComponent(data));
          const accessToken = parsedData.accessToken;

          if (accessToken) {
            localStorage.setItem("accessToken", accessToken);
          }

          const response = await axios.get(url, {
            headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}` },
          });

          setState({
            shoeStats: parsedData.gear,
            lastRun: {
              ...parsedData.lastRun,
              distance: parseFloat(parsedData.lastRun.distance),
            },
            totalKilometersLastWeek: response.data.totalKilometersLastWeek,
            totalKilometersCurrentWeek: response.data.totalKilometersCurrentWeek,
            loading: false,
          });
        } else {
          window.location.href = import.meta.env.VITE_STRAVA_AUTH_URL;
        }
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Error fetching run data:", error);
        setState((prevState) => ({ ...prevState, loading: false }));
      }
    };

    fetchData();
  }, []);

  return state;
}

Explanation of Changes

  • Removed isDemoMode and Demo Logic: The hook no longer checks for demo mode or uses a demo URL.
  • Single Data Source: It now solely uses VITE_RUNS_URL and fetches live data.
  • Error Handling and Redirects: If no data is found, it redirects to the Strava authentication URL.

Additional Clean-Up

  • Remove VITE_DEMO_RUNS_URL, VITE_DEMO_MODE, and any other demo-related environment variables from .env files and configurations.

This should leave you with a streamlined hook focused only on live data retrieval.

Pasakėte:
remove demo mode server.js require("dotenv").config(); const express = require("express"); const cors = require("cors"); const mongoose = require("mongoose"); const routes = require("./routes/indexRoutes"); const shoeRoutes = require("./routes/shoeRoutes"); const stravaAuthRoutes = require("./routes/stravaAuthRoutes"); const app = express(); const port = process.env.PORT || 5000; mongoose .connect(process.env.MONGODB_URI, {}) .then(() => console.log("MongoDB connected...")) .catch((err) => console.error("MongoDB connection error:", err)); app.use( cors({ origin: process.env.CORS_ORIGIN, credentials: true, }) ); app.use(express.json()); app.use("/api/shoes", shoeRoutes); app.use("/auth/strava", routes.stravaAuth); app.use("/api", stravaAuthRoutes); app.use("/api", routes.api); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(Server running on port ${port}); }); module.exports = app;
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To remove demo mode from server.js, we can delete any routes, middleware, or configurations related to demo mode. In your current server.js, there are no direct references to demo mode, so the changes are minimal.

Updated server.js

  1. Remove Demo-Related Routes or Middleware: Ensure that indexRoutes, shoeRoutes, and stravaAuthRoutes do not contain any demo-specific routes.
  2. Clean Up .env File: Remove any demo-specific environment variables from your .env file, such as VITE_DEMO_MODE, VITE_DEMO_RUNS_URL, or similar variables.

Here’s how your server.js will look with demo mode removed:

javascript
require("dotenv").config();
const express = require("express");
const cors = require("cors");
const mongoose = require("mongoose");
const routes = require("./routes/indexRoutes");
const shoeRoutes = require("./routes/shoeRoutes");
const stravaAuthRoutes = require("./routes/stravaAuthRoutes");

const app = express();
const port = process.env.PORT || 5000;

mongoose
  .connect(process.env.MONGODB_URI, {})
  .then(() => console.log("MongoDB connected..."))
  .catch((err) => console.error("MongoDB connection error:", err));

app.use(
  cors({
    origin: process.env.CORS_ORIGIN,
    credentials: true,
  })
);
app.use(express.json());
app.use("/api/shoes", shoeRoutes);
app.use("/auth/strava", routes.stravaAuth);
app.use("/api", stravaAuthRoutes);
app.use("/api", routes.api);

app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Server running on port ${port}`);
});

module.exports = app;

Additional Steps:

  • Confirm Routes: Check each file in routes and controllers directories to ensure no demo-related endpoints are still included.
  • Environment Variables: Remove any variables related to demo mode from your .env file.

This setup will now exclusively handle live data requests.

javascript
const express = require("express");
const { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback } = require("../controllers/stravaAccessController");

const router = express.Router();

// Strava Auth Route
router.get("/", (req, res) => getAuthUrl(req, res));

// Callback route to handle auth
router.get("/callback", (req, res) => handleAuthCallback(req, res));

module.exports = router;

Pasakėte:
Remove demo mode from my stravaAccessCOntroller.js const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); const STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN = process.env.STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN; /** * Redirects to the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @param {Object} req * @param {Object} res */ const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; /** * Handles the Strava OAuth callback, exchanges authorization code for access token, * and redirects to the frontend with user data. * @param {Object} req * @param {Object} res */ const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; /** * Fetches demo data using the STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN to display in demo mode. * @param {Object} req * @param {Object} res */ const getDemoData = async (req, res) => { try { const data = await getLastRunAndGear(STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN); res.json({ lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear, totalKilometersLastWeek: 57.31, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 30.14, }); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching demo data:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error fetching demo data" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, getDemoData, // Export the new demo data function };
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

To fully remove demo mode from stravaAccessController.js, we need to:

  1. Remove getDemoData and its logic.
  2. Delete the STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN reference.
  3. Adjust the module exports to remove getDemoData.

Here’s the updated code without demo mode:

javascript
const {
  generateAuthUrl,
  exchangeAuthorizationCode,
  getLastRunAndGear,
} = require("../services/stravaService");

/**
 * Redirects to the Strava OAuth authorization URL.
 * @param {Object} req
 * @param {Object} res
 */
const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => {
  const authUrl = generateAuthUrl();
  res.redirect(authUrl);
};

/**
 * Handles the Strava OAuth callback, exchanges authorization code for access token,
 * and redirects to the frontend with user data.
 * @param {Object} req
 * @param {Object} res
 */
const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => {
  const authorizationCode = req.query.code;

  if (!authorizationCode) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" });
  }

  try {
    const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode);
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);

    const redirectUri = `${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent(
      JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear })
    )}`;
    res.redirect(redirectUri);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during token exchange:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" });
  }
};

module.exports = {
  getAuthUrl,
  handleAuthCallback,
};

Summary of Changes

  • Removed the getDemoData function entirely.
  • Deleted the STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN constant.
  • Updated the module exports to include only getAuthUrl and handleAuthCallback.

Additional Step

  • Remove any references to STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN in your .env file to clean up unnecessary environment variables.
Pasakėte:
remove demo mode activity controller.js const { fetchRunsData } = require("../services/activityService"); const { calculateTotalKilometers } = require("../utils/dateUtils"); /** * Controller to fetch and return paginated runs, and calculate total kilometers for the last and current weeks. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const fetchRuns = async (req, res) => { const accessToken = req.headers.authorization; const page = parseInt(req.query.page) || 1; const limit = 5; if (!accessToken) { return res.status(401).json({ message: "Access token is required" }); } try { const runs = await fetchRunsData(accessToken); const totalKilometersLastWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 7); const totalKilometersCurrentWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 0); const paginatedRuns = runs.slice((page - 1) * limit, page * limit); res.json({ runs: paginatedRuns, total: runs.length, totalKilometersLastWeek, totalKilometersCurrentWeek, }); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Failed to fetch runs from Strava API" }); } }; module.exports = { fetchRuns };
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

In activityController.js, there are no explicit demo mode references in this code. However, to ensure any hidden demo mode logic is removed, let’s review the controller to confirm it’s fetching data directly from the Strava API without checking for any demo tokens or conditions.

The following changes finalize this cleanup:

  1. Remove any unused or unneeded environment variables related to demo mode from .env.
  2. Confirm fetchRunsData in activityService.js fetches data directly from Strava API without any demo mode conditions.

Here is the refined activityController.js:

javascript
const { fetchRunsData } = require("../services/activityService");
const { calculateTotalKilometers } = require("../utils/dateUtils");

/**
 * Controller to fetch and return paginated runs, and calculate total kilometers for the last and current weeks.
 * @param {Object} req - Express request object
 * @param {Object} res - Express response object
 */

const fetchRuns = async (req, res) => {
  const accessToken = req.headers.authorization;
  const page = parseInt(req.query.page) || 1;
  const limit = 5;

  if (!accessToken) {
    return res.status(401).json({ message: "Access token is required" });
  }

  try {
    const runs = await fetchRunsData(accessToken);
    const totalKilometersLastWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 7);
    const totalKilometersCurrentWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 0);

    const paginatedRuns = runs.slice((page - 1) * limit, page * limit);

    res.json({
      runs: paginatedRuns,
      total: runs.length,
      totalKilometersLastWeek,
      totalKilometersCurrentWeek,
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching runs:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Failed to fetch runs from Strava API" });
  }
};

module.exports = { fetchRuns };

Summary of Changes

  • Verified that no demo mode logic exists in fetchRuns.
  • Ensured fetchRunsData does not rely on any demo mode conditionals.

Once you confirm fetchRunsData in activityService.js aligns with this, demo mode will be fully removed from activityController.js.

„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The 500 (Internal Server Error) indicates an issue with the backend API endpoint at http://localhost:5000/api/runs. Here are some steps to help debug and address the issue:

  1. Check the Backend Logs:

    • Look at the console output or log files for your backend to identify the specific error causing the 500 response. The backend error message often provides helpful insights (e.g., database connection issues or token-related errors).

  2. Verify the /api/runs Route in the Backend:

    • Make sure that the /api/runs endpoint is correctly defined in your backend code, and that it’s part of the routes being handled.
    • In your backend code, confirm that fetchRuns is properly exported and used in the routing files.

  3. Check for Authorization Issues:

    • Verify that an authorization token is sent in the request headers. In useFetchRunData.js, the accessToken should be stored in localStorage.
    • In the backend, ensure that the token is validated and accepted by the Strava API. If there’s a refresh mechanism for tokens, confirm that it's implemented correctly to avoid expired tokens.

  4. Ensure the Database Connection:

    • If your backend relies on MongoDB or any other database, confirm that the database is running and accessible. Check your .env file for the correct MONGODB_URI.

  5. Backend Endpoint Testing:

    • Test the /api/runs endpoint directly with tools like Postman or curl. This can help you see if the issue lies with the endpoint itself, and it also allows you to send headers and inspect the raw response.

  6. Frontend Code (React) Adjustments:

    • Based on the warnings in your console:
      • For the ShoeStatistics component, ensure that shoeStats is initialized or add a conditional rendering check to only display it when it’s not null.
      • Similarly, for the LastRunData component, make sure lastRun is present before passing it to the component or initialize it with default values.

Example for Conditional Rendering in HomePage.jsx

To avoid warnings if shoeStats or lastRun are null, add checks like:

javascript
<Grid item xs={12} md={6}>
  {state.shoeStats && (
    <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} />
  )}
</Grid>
<Grid item xs={12} md={6}>
  {state.lastRun && (
    <LastRunData
      mapCenter={mapCenter}
      coordinates={coordinates}
      lastRun={state.lastRun}
      formatDuration={formatDuration}
    />
  )}
</Grid>

Next Steps

  1. Implement Conditional Error Handling in useFetchRunData.js:
    • Log any additional error messages from the backend response in the console for further debugging insights.

After following these steps, the exact cause of the 500 error should be easier to identify and resolve. Let me know if you need help with any specific debugging step based on what you find.

Pasakėte:

„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The error 500 (Internal Server Error) from http://localhost:5000/api/runs indicates an issue on the backend server side, and the additional warnings in the console suggest that shoeStats and lastRun are coming back as null. Here’s how to troubleshoot and resolve these issues:

Step 1: Debug the Backend API (/api/runs)

  1. Check Backend Logs: Look at the logs in your backend console for any specific error messages that might give you insight into the root cause of the 500 error. This often reveals if there’s an issue with data retrieval, token authorization, or database connections.

  2. Test /api/runs with Postman or Curl: Sending a request directly to http://localhost:5000/api/runs with the necessary authorization header can help you isolate if the endpoint works as expected or if it’s returning an error due to missing data or configurations.

  3. Verify Token Handling: Ensure that the backend is properly receiving and validating the token. Missing or invalid tokens often cause backend services to return a 500 or 401 error.

  4. Database Check: If shoeStats and lastRun data are retrieved from the database, ensure that the database connection is active and that the expected data exists in the collection.

Step 2: Handle Missing Data in Frontend (HomePage.jsx)

To avoid React warnings about missing props for shoeStats and lastRun, add conditional rendering checks in HomePage.jsx. This will allow the app to handle cases where the data is null or undefined without triggering warnings.

Update HomePage.jsx like this:

javascript
import { Box, Grid } from "@mui/material";
import polyline from "@mapbox/polyline";
import UserInfo from "../components/user/UserInfo";
import WeeklyStatistics from "../components/run/WeeklyStatistics";
import ShoeStatistics from "../components/shoes/ShoeStatistics";
import LastRunData from "../components/run/LastRunData";
import shoeImage from "../assets/images/nike-structure.png";
import useFetchRunData from "../hooks/useFetchRunData";

export default function HomePage() {
  const state = useFetchRunData();

  if (state.loading) return <div>Loading...</div>;

  const coordinates = state.lastRun?.summary_polyline
    ? polyline.decode(state.lastRun.summary_polyline)
    : [];
  const mapCenter = coordinates.length ? [coordinates[0][0], coordinates[0][1]] : [0, 0];

  const formatDuration = (movingTimeString) => {
    if (!movingTimeString) return "N/A";
    const minutesMatch = movingTimeString.match(/(\d+)\s*minutes/);
    if (minutesMatch) {
      const minutes = parseInt(minutesMatch[1], 10);
      return `${Math.floor(minutes / 60)}h ${minutes % 60}m`;
    }
    return "N/A";
  };

  return (
    <Box sx={{ p: 3, backgroundColor: "background.default" }}>
      <UserInfo username="UserName" />
      <Grid container spacing={3}>
        <Grid item xs={12}>
          <WeeklyStatistics
            totalKilometersLastWeek={state.totalKilometersLastWeek}
            totalKilometersCurrentWeek={state.totalKilometersCurrentWeek}
          />
        </Grid>
        <Grid item xs={12} md={6}>
          {state.shoeStats && (
            <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} />
          )}
        </Grid>
        <Grid item xs={12} md={6}>
          {state.lastRun && (
            <LastRunData
              mapCenter={mapCenter}
              coordinates={coordinates}
              lastRun={state.lastRun}
              formatDuration={formatDuration}
            />
          )}
        </Grid>
      </Grid>
    </Box>
  );
}

Step 3: Review and Update Backend Authorization and Data Retrieval

  • Ensure the backend is correctly fetching data from Strava or any other source and handling any potential errors gracefully.
  • Verify that any API calls to third-party services are successful, and that data is properly returned to the frontend.

Step 4: Test and Verify

  • Restart the backend server after making changes to ensure all updates are applied.
  • Test again from the frontend and ensure that you no longer see the 500 error and that the warnings for shoeStats and lastRun have been resolved.

Let me know if there’s anything specific in the backend logs that could provide further clues!
