The repeated 500 (Internal Server Error) messages and prop warnings suggest issues in both the backend and frontend components. Here’s a structured approach to help resolve these:

Step 1: Backend – Investigate /api/runs 500 Error

  1. Enable Detailed Error Logging in Backend:

    • Add a try-catch block with logging in the /api/runs route handler to capture any specific error messages.

  2. Test /api/runs Endpoint Directly:

    • Use a tool like curl or Postman to send a request directly to http://localhost:5000/api/runs.
    • If the response is still 500, this means the issue is server-side. Check if it’s due to authorization, missing data, or an invalid query.

  3. Check Access Tokens:

    • Ensure the access token being sent in the header is valid.
    • If using a refresh token mechanism, confirm it is correctly updating the token on expiry.

Step 2: Frontend – Handle Missing Props

To prevent ShoeStatistics and LastRunData from failing due to missing props:

  1. Set Default Prop Values in HomePage.jsx: Update ShoeStatistics and LastRunData components to use default values if shoeStats or lastRun is null.

    javascript
    <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats || {}} shoeImage={shoeImage} />
<LastRunData
   mapCenter={mapCenter}
   coordinates={coordinates}
   lastRun={state.lastRun || {}}
   formatDuration={formatDuration}
/>

  2. Verify API Data Structure:

    • Check that the backend returns the expected structure for shoeStats and lastRun.
    • If any data is missing, verify the data-fetching logic in the backend to ensure it matches what the frontend expects.

Step 3: Re-test and Observe Logs

  1. Restart Both Backend and Frontend to ensure changes are in effect.
  2. Watch the Backend Logs:
    • Any specific error messages related to the database or API response can give insight into the root of the 500 error.

Following these steps will help narrow down the exact source of the error and confirm whether it’s data, token, or code logic that’s failing. Let me know what specific error details emerge from these steps!

Pasakėte:
it got something to do with my .env file and authorization token can we build .env file based on my code ? server.js require("dotenv").config(); const express = require("express"); const cors = require("cors"); const mongoose = require("mongoose"); const routes = require("./routes/indexRoutes"); const shoeRoutes = require("./routes/shoeRoutes"); const app = express(); const port = process.env.PORT || 5000; mongoose .connect(process.env.MONGODB_URI, {}) .then(() => console.log("MongoDB connected...")) .catch((err) => console.error("MongoDB connection error:", err)); app.use( cors({ origin: process.env.CORS_ORIGIN || "http://localhost:5173", credentials: true, }) ); app.use(express.json()); app.use("/api/shoes", shoeRoutes); app.use("/auth/strava", routes.stravaAuth); app.use("/api", routes.api); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(Server running on port ${port}); }); module.exports = app; StravaService.js const axios = require("axios"); const querystring = require("querystring"); /** * Generates the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @returns {string} - The authorization URL for Strava OAuth */ function generateAuthUrl() { const clientId = process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID; const redirectUri = process.env.STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI; return https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=${clientId}&response_type=code&redirect_uri=${redirectUri}&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all; } /** * Exchanges an authorization code for an access token. * @param {string} authorizationCode - The authorization code from Strava * @returns {string} - The access token * @throws Will throw an error if the token exchange fails */ async function exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode) { try { const response = await axios.post( "https://www.strava.com/oauth/token", querystring.stringify({ client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID, client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET, code: authorizationCode, grant_type: "authorization_code", }) ); return response.data.access_token; } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); throw new Error("Failed to exchange authorization code for access token"); } } /** * Fetches the athlete's recent activities and returns the last run. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {Object} - Data for the last run * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the last run fails */ async function getLastRun(accessToken) { try { const response = await axios.get( "https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, params: { per_page: 10 }, } ); const lastRun = response.data.find((activity) => activity.type === "Run"); if (!lastRun) { return { message: "No run found in recent activities" }; } return { id: lastRun.id, name: lastRun.name, distance: (lastRun.distance / 1000).toFixed(2), moving_time: ${(lastRun.moving_time / 60).toFixed(0)} minutes, date: new Date(lastRun.start_date).toLocaleDateString(), summary_polyline: lastRun.map.summary_polyline, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching last run data:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run data from Strava"); } } /** * Fetches the athlete's profile to retrieve the primary shoe ID. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {string|null} - The ID of the primary shoe, or null if none found * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the athlete profile fails */ async function getAthleteProfile(accessToken) { try { const response = await axios.get("https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, }); return response.data.shoes?.[0]?.id || null; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching athlete profile:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch athlete profile from Strava"); } } /** * Fetches the details for a specific piece of gear (e.g., primary shoes). * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @param {string} gearId - ID of the gear to retrieve * @returns {Object} - Gear details including name and total mileage * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the gear details fails */ async function getGearDetails(accessToken, gearId) { try { const response = await axios.get( https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear/${gearId}, { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, } ); return { name: response.data.name, totalMileage: ${(response.data.distance / 1000).toFixed(2)} km, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching gear details:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch gear details from Strava"); } } /** * Retrieves both the last run and gear details for an athlete. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {Object} - Contains last run details and gear information * @throws Will throw an error if fetching either the last run or gear fails */ async function getLastRunAndGear(accessToken) { try { const lastRun = await getLastRun(accessToken); const gearId = await getAthleteProfile(accessToken); const gearDetails = gearId ? await getGearDetails(accessToken, gearId) : null; return { lastRun, gear: gearDetails || { message: "No gear found or no shoes set" }, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching last run and gear data:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run and gear details from Strava"); } } module.exports = { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, }; activityService.js const axios = require("axios"); /** * Fetch activities from Strava API and filter for "Run" activities * @param {string} accessToken - User's access token * @returns {Array} - Array of running activities */ const fetchRunsData = async (accessToken) => { const response = await axios.get( "https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, params: { per_page: 100, page: 1 }, } ); return response.data.filter((activity) => activity.type === "Run"); }; module.exports = { fetchRunsData }; StravaAccessCOntroller.js const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); /** * Redirects to the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; /** * Handles the Strava OAuth callback, exchanges authorization code for access token, * and redirects to the frontend with user data. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, }; activityCOntroller.js const { fetchRunsData } = require("../services/activityService"); const { calculateTotalKilometers } = require("../utils/dateUtils"); /** * Controller to fetch and return paginated runs, and calculate total kilometers for the last and current weeks. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const fetchRuns = async (req, res) => { const accessToken = req.headers.authorization; const page = parseInt(req.query.page) || 1; const limit = 5; if (!accessToken) { return res.status(401).json({ message: "Access token is required" }); } try { const runs = await fetchRunsData(accessToken); const totalKilometersLastWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 7); const totalKilometersCurrentWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 0); const paginatedRuns = runs.slice((page - 1) * limit, page * limit); res.json({ runs: paginatedRuns, total: runs.length, totalKilometersLastWeek, totalKilometersCurrentWeek, }); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Failed to fetch runs from Strava API" }); } }; module.exports = { fetchRuns }; CHECK ALL MY CODE AND SEE IF THE PROBLEM IS NOT IN THE .ENV BASED ON MY CODE HELP ME GENERATE NEW .ENV CODES
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Your .env file may indeed need updates or corrections to ensure compatibility with your Strava authentication and backend service configurations. Based on the code you've shared, I'll outline a recommended .env configuration, pointing out necessary values and troubleshooting points for each section.

Suggested .env Configuration

Make sure to replace placeholders like <YOUR_ACTUAL_VALUES> with the actual values as indicated below.

plaintext
# Strava Application Settings
STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=<YOUR_STRAVA_CLIENT_ID>            # e.g., 138288
STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=<YOUR_STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET>    # Your Strava App's Client Secret
STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback
STRAVA_AUTH_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize
STRAVA_TOKEN_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/token
STRAVA_ACTIVITIES_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities
STRAVA_ATHLETE_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete
STRAVA_GEAR_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear

# Refresh Token (Optional if not using automatic refresh)
# STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=<YOUR_INITIAL_REFRESH_TOKEN>

# Tokens and Secrets
ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET=<A_LONG_RANDOM_SECRET_STRING>   # Used for JWT or token storage
REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET=<A_DIFFERENT_RANDOM_SECRET>    # Used for JWT refresh tokens if applicable

# MongoDB Configuration
MONGODB_URI=mongodb://localhost:27017/runtrackr      # MongoDB connection URI

# Frontend Configuration
FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173                   # Frontend app URL for redirection after auth
CORS_ORIGIN=http://localhost:5173                    # CORS allowed origin

# Server Configuration
PORT=5000                                            # Server Port

Explanation and Troubleshooting Steps

  1. Strava Client and Secret Values:

    • STRAVA_CLIENT_ID and STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET must match the exact credentials from the Strava developer dashboard.
    • These values are used to obtain an authorization code and an access token.

  2. Redirect URI:

    • The STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI should match the URI configured in the Strava developer dashboard.
    • Ensure this is set as http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback both in .env and on Strava's developer site.

  3. Token URLs:

    • Ensure URLs like STRAVA_AUTH_URL, STRAVA_TOKEN_URL, STRAVA_ACTIVITIES_URL, STRAVA_ATHLETE_URL, and STRAVA_GEAR_URL are set as shown, as these are consistent with Strava's API endpoint structure.

  4. Access and Refresh Token Secrets:

    • The ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET and REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET values are typically used in JWT-based authentication. Generate long, random strings to ensure security.

  5. MongoDB URI:

    • MONGODB_URI should match the database setup on your local system or a remote MongoDB instance.
    • If you’re using a local setup, confirm that MongoDB is running on port 27017.

  6. Frontend URL and CORS Origin:

    • FRONTEND_URL and CORS_ORIGIN should be http://localhost:5173 to match your frontend app running on this port with Vite.
    • Ensure your CORS setup in server.js allows requests from this origin.

  7. Server Port:

    • PORT=5000 aligns with the port your backend server is using. This should match the backend server setup.

Testing Steps

  1. Verify .env Loading:

    • Restart your server after saving the .env changes to make sure the new values are loaded.

  2. Check for Authorization Errors:

    • Re-run the authorization flow by navigating to the Strava auth URL, obtaining a new authorization code, and exchanging it for an access token.
    • Ensure that any token received is being passed correctly in requests.

  3. Use dotenv Debugging:

    • Add console.log(process.env) at the top of server.js (temporarily) to verify that each .env value is being loaded correctly.
    • Remove this line after confirming the values are loaded as expected.

This setup, along with these steps, should address any environment-related issues impacting Strava authentication and resource loading. Let me know if you encounter any further issues or specific error messages after testing these changes!

Pasakėte:
where and how to obtain STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN,ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET,REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET ?
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Here's how you can obtain and set the values for STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN, ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET, and REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET in your .env file:

1. STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN

The STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN is used to request new access tokens from Strava without requiring the user to reauthorize every time the access token expires.

Steps to Obtain STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN:

  1. Authorize the User: Go through the Strava OAuth process by visiting the authorization URL you already have set up:
    plaintext
    https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=<YOUR_CLIENT_ID>&response_type=code&redirect_uri=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all
  2. Get Authorization Code: After you authorize the application, Strava will redirect you with a code parameter (the authorization code) in the URL.
  3. Exchange the Code for a Token: Use the authorization code to obtain an access token and refresh token by running the following curl command (replacing <YOUR_CLIENT_ID>, <YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET>, and <AUTHORIZATION_CODE> with your details):
    bash
    curl -X POST https://www.strava.com/oauth/token \
  -F client_id=<YOUR_CLIENT_ID> \
  -F client_secret=<YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET> \
  -F code=<AUTHORIZATION_CODE> \
  -F grant_type=authorization_code
  4. Save the Refresh Token:
    • The response will include access_token and refresh_token. Save the value of refresh_token in your .env as STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN.
  5. Example Response:
    json
    {
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "access_token": "ACCESS_TOKEN_VALUE",
  "expires_at": 1607353891,
  "expires_in": 21600,
  "refresh_token": "YOUR_REFRESH_TOKEN"
}
    Save the refresh_token in your .env file:
    plaintext
    STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=YOUR_REFRESH_TOKEN

2. ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET and REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET

These values are secret strings used in your application to secure JWTs or session tokens. They are specific to your app and don’t come from Strava. Here’s how to generate them:

How to Generate ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET and REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET:

  • Use a terminal command to generate a long, random string for each:
    bash
    # Generate a 64-character random string
openssl rand -hex 32
  • Run this command twice to generate one for ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET and one for REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET.
  • Save the values in your .env file:
    plaintext
    ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET=YOUR_GENERATED_ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET
REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET=YOUR_GENERATED_REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET

These secrets are used by your backend to sign tokens or verify sessions securely. Make sure not to share these values publicly or expose them in your codebase.

After setting these values in your .env, restart your server to ensure that they’re loaded. This setup should now allow your app to handle secure access token refreshes and authenticated requests.

Pasakėte:
also redirect uri
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Your redirect_uri is a critical part of the OAuth flow as it’s where Strava will send the authorization code once a user grants permission. This URI must match what you’ve set in your Strava developer application settings.

Here’s how to set up and troubleshoot the redirect_uri:

1. Define the Redirect URI in Your Application’s Strava Settings

  1. Go to Strava Developer Portal:
    • Log in to your Strava API Application Management.
  2. Add Redirect URI:
    • In your application's settings, look for a section labeled “Authorization Callback Domain” or “Redirect URI.”
    • Set this field to match your application’s backend endpoint that will handle the callback.
    • For local development, this will be:
      plaintext
      http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback
    • Save your changes.

2. Set the Redirect URI in Your .env File

In your .env file, add the following:

plaintext
STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback
  • Make sure this URI is consistent in both your .env and Strava application settings.

3. Update Your OAuth Authorization URL to Use the Correct Redirect URI

In your code, the authorization URL generation function (generateAuthUrl) should pull the redirect URI from the environment variable STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI. Ensure that your generateAuthUrl function uses this variable properly, as shown in your StravaService.js file:

javascript
function generateAuthUrl() {
  const clientId = process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID;
  const redirectUri = process.env.STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI;
  return `https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=${clientId}&response_type=code&redirect_uri=${redirectUri}&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all`;
}

4. Verify the Authorization Flow

  1. Access the Authorization URL in your browser. For example:
    plaintext
    https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID&response_type=code&redirect_uri=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all
  2. Grant Authorization: Strava will redirect back to the URI specified in redirect_uri with a code parameter.
  3. Check the Callback: Confirm that your backend at http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback receives this code correctly.

Common Issues

  • Mismatch Errors: If you encounter redirect_uri mismatch, double-check that the URI in the Strava settings, .env file, and OAuth request are all identical.
  • Incorrect Environment Variables: Ensure that your backend is actually reading from .env by restarting the server after any changes to .env.

With these steps, your redirect_uri should be correctly configured for both Strava and your application’s authorization flow.

Pasakėte:
after i go thrue authentication i dont get any authorization code, i only got redirected to my front end
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

If you're not receiving an authorization code after authenticating, there might be an issue with your backend callback route or the way Strava handles the authorization response. Here are some steps to troubleshoot and ensure that your code is handling the response correctly:

1. Verify the Redirect URI Setup

  • Ensure that the redirect URI specified in your Strava app settings matches the one in your .env file and the authorization URL exactly. It should be pointing to your backend endpoint that handles the callback, not directly to your frontend.
    • Example: http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback

2. Inspect Your Callback Route in StravaAccessController.js

Your callback function in StravaAccessController.js should be set up to handle and log the received authorization code. Here’s how it should look:

javascript
const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => {
  const authorizationCode = req.query.code; // Retrieve the code parameter

  if (!authorizationCode) {
    console.error("Authorization code missing from query parameters.");
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" });
  }

  try {
    const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode);
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);

    const redirectUri = `${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent(
      JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear })
    )}`;
    res.redirect(redirectUri);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during token exchange:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" });
  }
};

3. Check Console Logs for Authorization Code

Add a console.log inside the handleAuthCallback function to check if authorizationCode is received:

javascript
console.log("Authorization Code:", authorizationCode);

4. Ensure Correct Redirection After Token Exchange

After obtaining the access token, you should be redirecting to the frontend with relevant data. Verify that this part works:

javascript
const redirectUri = `${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent(
  JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear })
)}`;
res.redirect(redirectUri);

5. Check Network Requests in Developer Tools

Use your browser's developer tools to:

  • Confirm that the URL includes a code parameter after you authorize in Strava.
  • Inspect the network requests to see if the request to http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback is being made and contains the code.

6. Troubleshoot Common Issues

  • Missing Authorization Code: Ensure that you’re not bypassing or overwriting the code parameter in any other middleware.
  • Frontend Redirection Issue: If Strava is redirecting directly to the frontend without going through the backend, double-check your Strava application settings.

Let me know if any logs or network responses indicate further issues. This should help clarify where the callback handling might be falling short.

Pasakėte:
once https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=138288&response_type=code&redirect_uri=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all i get { "message": "Bad Request", "errors": [ { "resource": "Application", "field": "client_id", "code": "invalid" } ] }
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The "invalid client_id" error usually indicates that Strava is not recognizing the client_id you’re providing. Here are steps to troubleshoot and fix this issue:

1. Verify client_id and client_secret

Make sure the client_id and client_secret match the ones in your Strava developer application settings:

  • Go to the Strava Developer Dashboard: https://www.strava.com/settings/api
  • Confirm your Client ID and Client Secret: Verify they are correct in your .env file and in the authorization URL you’re using.

Your .env variables should look like this:

plaintext
STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=YOUR_ACTUAL_CLIENT_ID  # e.g., 12345
STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=YOUR_ACTUAL_CLIENT_SECRET
STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback

Replace YOUR_ACTUAL_CLIENT_ID and YOUR_ACTUAL_CLIENT_SECRET with your actual values.

2. Update Authorization URL with Correct client_id

If you confirmed that client_id is correct in the .env, ensure you’re using the correct value in the authorization URL:

plaintext
https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=YOUR_ACTUAL_CLIENT_ID&response_type=code&redirect_uri=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all

Replace YOUR_ACTUAL_CLIENT_ID with the verified client_id from your Strava settings.

3. Check for Whitelisted Redirect URI

Strava enforces that the redirect URI you provide in the URL exactly matches the one configured in the Strava developer settings.

  • In the Strava Developer Dashboard, ensure the Redirect URI is set to:
    plaintext
    http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback

4. Regenerate and Test Authorization URL

Try visiting the authorization URL again:

plaintext
https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=YOUR_ACTUAL_CLIENT_ID&response_type=code&redirect_uri=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all

If these steps don’t resolve the issue, please let me know if there’s any additional detail in the error logs, and we can look into further troubleshooting.

Pasakėte:
Can you check if everything set up correctly in my code to use .env file ? StravaAccessCOntroller.js const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); /** * Redirects to the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; /** * Handles the Strava OAuth callback, exchanges authorization code for access token, * and redirects to the frontend with user data. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, }; ActivityControllers.js const { fetchRunsData } = require("../services/activityService"); const { calculateTotalKilometers } = require("../utils/dateUtils"); /** * Controller to fetch and return paginated runs, and calculate total kilometers for the last and current weeks. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const fetchRuns = async (req, res) => { const accessToken = req.headers.authorization; const page = parseInt(req.query.page) || 1; const limit = 5; if (!accessToken) { return res.status(401).json({ message: "Access token is required" }); } try { const runs = await fetchRunsData(accessToken); const totalKilometersLastWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 7); const totalKilometersCurrentWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 0); const paginatedRuns = runs.slice((page - 1) * limit, page * limit); res.json({ runs: paginatedRuns, total: runs.length, totalKilometersLastWeek, totalKilometersCurrentWeek, }); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Failed to fetch runs from Strava API" }); } }; module.exports = { fetchRuns }; StravaServices.js const axios = require("axios"); const querystring = require("querystring"); /** * Generates the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @returns {string} - The authorization URL for Strava OAuth */ function generateAuthUrl() { const clientId = process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID; const redirectUri = process.env.STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI; return https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=${clientId}&response_type=code&redirect_uri=${redirectUri}&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all; } /** * Exchanges an authorization code for an access token. * @param {string} authorizationCode - The authorization code from Strava * @returns {string} - The access token * @throws Will throw an error if the token exchange fails */ async function exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode) { try { const response = await axios.post( "https://www.strava.com/oauth/token", querystring.stringify({ client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID, client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET, code: authorizationCode, grant_type: "authorization_code", }) ); return response.data.access_token; } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); throw new Error("Failed to exchange authorization code for access token"); } } /** * Fetches the athlete's recent activities and returns the last run. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {Object} - Data for the last run * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the last run fails */ async function getLastRun(accessToken) { try { const response = await axios.get( "https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, params: { per_page: 10 }, } ); const lastRun = response.data.find((activity) => activity.type === "Run"); if (!lastRun) { return { message: "No run found in recent activities" }; } return { id: lastRun.id, name: lastRun.name, distance: (lastRun.distance / 1000).toFixed(2), moving_time: ${(lastRun.moving_time / 60).toFixed(0)} minutes, date: new Date(lastRun.start_date).toLocaleDateString(), summary_polyline: lastRun.map.summary_polyline, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching last run data:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run data from Strava"); } } /** * Fetches the athlete's profile to retrieve the primary shoe ID. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {string|null} - The ID of the primary shoe, or null if none found * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the athlete profile fails */ async function getAthleteProfile(accessToken) { try { const response = await axios.get("https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, }); return response.data.shoes?.[0]?.id || null; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching athlete profile:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch athlete profile from Strava"); } } /** * Fetches the details for a specific piece of gear (e.g., primary shoes). * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @param {string} gearId - ID of the gear to retrieve * @returns {Object} - Gear details including name and total mileage * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the gear details fails */ async function getGearDetails(accessToken, gearId) { try { const response = await axios.get( https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear/${gearId}, { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, } ); return { name: response.data.name, totalMileage: ${(response.data.distance / 1000).toFixed(2)} km, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching gear details:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch gear details from Strava"); } } /** * Retrieves both the last run and gear details for an athlete. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {Object} - Contains last run details and gear information * @throws Will throw an error if fetching either the last run or gear fails */ async function getLastRunAndGear(accessToken) { try { const lastRun = await getLastRun(accessToken); const gearId = await getAthleteProfile(accessToken); const gearDetails = gearId ? await getGearDetails(accessToken, gearId) : null; return { lastRun, gear: gearDetails || { message: "No gear found or no shoes set" }, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching last run and gear data:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run and gear details from Strava"); } } module.exports = { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, }; server.js require("dotenv").config(); const express = require("express"); const cors = require("cors"); const mongoose = require("mongoose"); const routes = require("./routes/indexRoutes"); const shoeRoutes = require("./routes/shoeRoutes"); const app = express(); const port = process.env.PORT || 5000; mongoose .connect(process.env.MONGODB_URI, {}) .then(() => console.log("MongoDB connected...")) .catch((err) => console.error("MongoDB connection error:", err)); app.use( cors({ origin: process.env.CORS_ORIGIN || "http://localhost:5173", credentials: true, }) ); app.use(express.json()); app.use("/api/shoes", shoeRoutes); app.use("/auth/strava", routes.stravaAuth); app.use("/api", routes.api); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(Server running on port ${port}); }); module.exports = app;
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Here’s a review of your setup to ensure that .env variables are correctly integrated. I’ll break down the key elements in each file and provide a checklist for the .env configuration.

1. .env File Checklist

Based on your code, your .env file should contain the following variables:

plaintext
# Strava API credentials
STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=your_client_id
STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=your_client_secret

# Tokens (ensure to add valid tokens if needed)
STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=your_refresh_token
ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET=your_access_token_secret
REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET=your_refresh_token_secret

# Redirect URL
STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback

# Frontend and backend settings
FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173
CORS_ORIGIN=http://localhost:5173
PORT=5000

# MongoDB URI
MONGODB_URI=mongodb://localhost:27017/runtrackr
  1. Confirm Values: Ensure the STRAVA_CLIENT_ID and STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET match the values in your Strava developer dashboard.
  2. STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI: The redirect URI in Strava settings should match http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback.
  3. MongoDB Connection: Confirm MONGODB_URI points to a running MongoDB instance.

2. Verify server.js Setup

In server.js, you are correctly loading .env using dotenv.config(), and environment variables are used for PORT, CORS_ORIGIN, and MONGODB_URI. The structure here is sound.

3. StravaService.js – .env Usage

In StravaService.js, ensure:

  • The generateAuthUrl() function uses STRAVA_CLIENT_ID and STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI.
  • The exchangeAuthorizationCode() function correctly uses STRAVA_CLIENT_ID and STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET when exchanging the authorization code for the access token.

This setup looks good. Ensure that these values in .env are correct.

4. StravaAccessController.js

In StravaAccessController.js:

  • The getAuthUrl() function should correctly redirect users to the authorization URL generated by generateAuthUrl().
  • In handleAuthCallback(), the code:
    • Retrieves code from req.query.code.
    • Calls exchangeAuthorizationCode() with this code, which uses the .env variables.
    • Redirects to FRONTEND_URL after fetching lastRun and gear.

The code structure is correct here. Just ensure that FRONTEND_URL is set correctly in .env and that the environment variables are accessible within StravaService.js.

5. Common Issues and Fixes

  • Restart Server: After any changes in the .env file, restart the server to load the latest values.
  • Access Token Refresh: If you haven’t set STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN and other token-related variables in .env, make sure they are either hardcoded (for testing only) or dynamically generated.
  • Error Handling: Ensure that error messages in StravaService.js and StravaAccessController.js correctly log detailed errors, as shown. This can help pinpoint missing values or invalid tokens.

6. Testing Setup

  1. Test the Authorization URL: Visit the authorization URL and confirm it redirects to Strava’s authentication page.
  2. Check Callback: After authorizing, confirm that Strava correctly redirects to your FRONTEND_URL with accessToken and other user data.

Let me know if there are any specific issues after verifying these steps!

„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The 401 Unauthorized error in the backend suggests that there is an issue with the access token being used in the request. Here are some troubleshooting steps and potential fixes that should help you identify and solve the issue.

1. Check the exchangeAuthorizationCode Function

First, ensure that the exchangeAuthorizationCode function correctly exchanges the authorization code for a valid access token. Specifically, check if the token is being returned correctly and is not empty.

javascript
// Ensure this function is working as expected
async function exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode) {
  try {
    const response = await axios.post(
      process.env.STRAVA_TOKEN_URL,
      querystring.stringify({
        client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID,
        client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET,
        code: authorizationCode,
        grant_type: "authorization_code",
      })
    );
    const { access_token } = response.data;
    if (!access_token) {
      throw new Error("Failed to retrieve access token");
    }
    return access_token;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during token exchange:", error);
    throw new Error("Failed to exchange authorization code for access token");
  }
}

2. Verify Access Token Handling

In StravaAccessController.js, after obtaining the access token, confirm that it’s being passed to the frontend and saved correctly. If you’re seeing an access token being sent, verify that it is indeed valid.

Add a console.log to check the token's value in handleAuthCallback:

javascript
const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => {
  const authorizationCode = req.query.code;
  if (!authorizationCode) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" });
  }

  try {
    const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode);
    console.log("Access Token:", accessToken); // Add this for debugging
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);

    const redirectUri = `${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent(
      JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear })
    )}`;
    res.redirect(redirectUri);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during token exchange:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" });
  }
};

3. Backend Request Headers – Double "Bearer" Issue

The console output shows an Authorization header with Bearer Bearer, which suggests the token is being prefixed twice. This can be corrected by removing any additional "Bearer" prefixes in the headers.

Check where the authorization token is being set in the request headers:

javascript
// Ensure only one "Bearer" prefix in headers
const fetchRunsData = async (accessToken) => {
  const response = await axios.get(process.env.STRAVA_ACTIVITIES_URL, {
    headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}` },
    params: { per_page: 100, page: 1 },
  });
  return response.data.filter((activity) => activity.type === "Run");
};

4. Verify .env Variables and Refresh Token Process

If you are using a refresh token to obtain a new access token when expired, ensure your environment variables in .env file are correctly set:

plaintext
# Strava API credentials
STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=your_client_id
STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=your_client_secret
STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback

# Frontend and backend settings
FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173
CORS_ORIGIN=http://localhost:5173
PORT=5000

# MongoDB URI
MONGODB_URI=mongodb://localhost:27017/runtrackr

5. Debugging Access Tokens in Frontend Requests

Check that the frontend correctly sends the access token to the backend in the authorization header. The token should be prefixed by only one Bearer:

javascript
const fetchRuns = async () => {
  try {
    const response = await axios.get("http://localhost:5000/api/runs", {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}`, // Single "Bearer" prefix
      },
    });
    return response.data;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching run data:", error);
    throw error;
  }
};

6. Regenerate and Reauthorize the Client ID and Secret on Strava

If the above steps don’t resolve the issue, try regenerating your STRAVA_CLIENT_ID and STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET from the Strava developer portal and updating your .env file accordingly.

Testing the Updated Code

  1. Restart your backend server after making changes.
  2. Reauthenticate using the Strava OAuth link.
  3. Confirm that the console.log outputs the correct access token in handleAuthCallback.
  4. Check that the frontend receives the token and includes it in requests to the backend with a single Bearer prefix.

These adjustments should help you identify the root of the 401 issue. Let me know if you run into additional errors after these changes!

Pasakėte:
debug everything here is my stravaService.js const axios = require("axios"); const querystring = require("querystring"); /** * Generates the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @returns {string} - The authorization URL for Strava OAuth */ function generateAuthUrl() { const clientId = process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID; const redirectUri = process.env.STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI; return https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=${clientId}&response_type=code&redirect_uri=${redirectUri}&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all; } /** * Exchanges an authorization code for an access token. * @param {string} authorizationCode - The authorization code from Strava * @returns {string} - The access token * @throws Will throw an error if the token exchange fails */ async function exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode) { try { const response = await axios.post( "https://www.strava.com/oauth/token", querystring.stringify({ client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID, client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET, code: authorizationCode, grant_type: "authorization_code", }) ); return response.data.access_token; } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); throw new Error("Failed to exchange authorization code for access token"); } } /** * Fetches the athlete's recent activities and returns the last run. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {Object} - Data for the last run * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the last run fails */ async function getLastRun(accessToken) { try { const response = await axios.get( "https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, params: { per_page: 10 }, } ); const lastRun = response.data.find((activity) => activity.type === "Run"); if (!lastRun) { return { message: "No run found in recent activities" }; } return { id: lastRun.id, name: lastRun.name, distance: (lastRun.distance / 1000).toFixed(2), moving_time: ${(lastRun.moving_time / 60).toFixed(0)} minutes, date: new Date(lastRun.start_date).toLocaleDateString(), summary_polyline: lastRun.map.summary_polyline, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching last run data:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run data from Strava"); } } /** * Fetches the athlete's profile to retrieve the primary shoe ID. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {string|null} - The ID of the primary shoe, or null if none found * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the athlete profile fails */ async function getAthleteProfile(accessToken) { try { const response = await axios.get("https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, }); return response.data.shoes?.[0]?.id || null; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching athlete profile:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch athlete profile from Strava"); } } /** * Fetches the details for a specific piece of gear (e.g., primary shoes). * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @param {string} gearId - ID of the gear to retrieve * @returns {Object} - Gear details including name and total mileage * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the gear details fails */ async function getGearDetails(accessToken, gearId) { try { const response = await axios.get( https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear/${gearId}, { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, } ); return { name: response.data.name, totalMileage: ${(response.data.distance / 1000).toFixed(2)} km, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching gear details:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch gear details from Strava"); } } /** * Retrieves both the last run and gear details for an athlete. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {Object} - Contains last run details and gear information * @throws Will throw an error if fetching either the last run or gear fails */ async function getLastRunAndGear(accessToken) { try { const lastRun = await getLastRun(accessToken); const gearId = await getAthleteProfile(accessToken); const gearDetails = gearId ? await getGearDetails(accessToken, gearId) : null; return { lastRun, gear: gearDetails || { message: "No gear found or no shoes set" }, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching last run and gear data:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run and gear details from Strava"); } } module.exports = { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, }; StravaAccessController.js const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); /** * Redirects to the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; /** * Handles the Strava OAuth callback, exchanges authorization code for access token, * and redirects to the frontend with user data. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, };
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Looking at your code, let's walk through it step-by-step to ensure the Strava integration works as intended and troubleshoot the issue:

Step-by-Step Debugging and Validation

  1. Confirm Environment Variables in .env File

    Ensure you have all the necessary variables set correctly in your .env file:

    plaintext
    STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=your_client_id
STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=your_client_secret
STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback
FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173
PORT=5000

    If any variable is incorrect or missing, Strava’s authorization process may not work properly. Double-check these values in your Strava Developer settings.

  2. Validate generateAuthUrl Function

    Ensure the authorization URL is being generated correctly:

    javascript
    function generateAuthUrl() {
  const clientId = process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID;
  const redirectUri = process.env.STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI;
  return `https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=${clientId}&response_type=code&redirect_uri=${redirectUri}&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all`;
}

    Run the function manually or print its output to the console:

    javascript
    console.log(generateAuthUrl());

    Go to the URL in the output, and ensure it leads to the correct Strava authorization page.

  3. Confirm Authorization Code Exchange

    Ensure that exchangeAuthorizationCode properly exchanges the authorization code for an access token:

    javascript
    async function exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode) {
  try {
    const response = await axios.post(
      "https://www.strava.com/oauth/token",
      querystring.stringify({
        client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID,
        client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET,
        code: authorizationCode,
        grant_type: "authorization_code",
      })
    );
    console.log("Token exchange response:", response.data); // Add logging
    return response.data.access_token;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during token exchange:", error.response?.data || error);
    throw new Error("Failed to exchange authorization code for access token");
  }
}

    After getting the authorization code, confirm that this function outputs a valid access token to the console.

  4. Check for Issues with getLastRun Function

    The getLastRun function uses the access token to make a request. If this token is invalid, Strava will respond with a 401 Unauthorized error:

    javascript
    async function getLastRun(accessToken) {
  try {
    const response = await axios.get("https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities", {
      headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}` },
      params: { per_page: 10 },
    });
    console.log("Fetched activities:", response.data); // Debug output
    const lastRun = response.data.find((activity) => activity.type === "Run");
    return lastRun ? formatRun(lastRun) : { message: "No run found in recent activities" };
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching last run data:", error.response?.data || error);
    throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run data from Strava");
  }
}

function formatRun(lastRun) {
  return {
    id: lastRun.id,
    name: lastRun.name,
    distance: (lastRun.distance / 1000).toFixed(2),
    moving_time: `${(lastRun.moving_time / 60).toFixed(0)} minutes`,
    date: new Date(lastRun.start_date).toLocaleDateString(),
    summary_polyline: lastRun.map.summary_polyline,
  };
}

    If console.log("Fetched activities:", response.data); logs an empty array or a 401 Unauthorized, there might be an issue with the token or permissions.

  5. Check the Authorization Header for Duplicate "Bearer" Prefix

    Ensure that you only have a single Bearer prefix in the Authorization header:

    javascript
    headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}` }

    If you see Bearer Bearer ..., update the code where the header is being set.

  6. Handle Missing Authorization Code in handleAuthCallback

    Confirm that the authorizationCode is successfully passed in the callback URL and is being captured by the handleAuthCallback controller. Use console.log to check if the authorizationCode is correctly received:

    javascript
    const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => {
  const authorizationCode = req.query.code;
  console.log("Authorization Code:", authorizationCode); // Debug output
  if (!authorizationCode) {
    return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" });
  }

  try {
    const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode);
    console.log("Access Token:", accessToken); // Confirm token reception
    const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken);

    const redirectUri = `${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent(
      JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear })
    )}`;
    res.redirect(redirectUri);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during token exchange:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" });
  }
};

    Final Tests

    1. Check Logs for Correct Values:

      • Confirm that the authorization code is present.
      • Confirm that the access token is retrieved successfully.
      • Confirm that activities are fetched correctly.

    2. Reauthorize if Necessary: If any issue persists with the authorization process, revoke access on Strava's developer portal and reauthorize.

Pasakėte:
https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=${clientId}&response_type=code&redirect_uri=${redirectUri}&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all; maybe problem is here ?
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

The URL syntax you’ve provided looks correct in general structure. However, let’s check some possible issues that might prevent the OAuth process from working as expected:

  1. Check client_id and redirect_uri Values:

    • Ensure that client_id and redirect_uri in your .env file are exactly as configured in your Strava Developer Application. If either value doesn’t match the application settings, you’ll get an "Invalid Client ID" or "Invalid Redirect URI" error.

  2. URL Encoding for Redirect URI:

    • The redirect_uri should be URL-encoded to ensure special characters (like colons, slashes, etc.) are correctly interpreted. If not already encoded, update the code to encode it:
      javascript
      const redirectUri = encodeURIComponent(process.env.STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI);
const authUrl = `https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=${clientId}&response_type=code&redirect_uri=${redirectUri}&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all`;

  3. Test authUrl Output:

    • Log the generated authUrl to verify it:
      javascript
      console.log("Generated Auth URL:", authUrl);
    • Copy and paste this URL into your browser manually. If it works there but not in your code, the issue might be elsewhere.

  4. Remove Unnecessary Parameters (If Applicable):

    • Sometimes, approval_prompt=force is not required and can be removed if you’re not seeing the prompt as expected. Additionally, confirm that the scope parameter values match those set up in your Strava Developer Application.

By checking each of these steps, you should be able to pinpoint any issues with authUrl generation. Let me know if any additional issues come up after these tests.

Pasakėte:
Maybe problem is in front end code ?
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Yes, the issue could also stem from the frontend code, especially if the data from Strava isn't being handled correctly after the redirect back to the frontend. Here’s a checklist to help diagnose any frontend issues related to the Strava OAuth process:

  1. Check Redirect URI Handling:

    • After the redirect, ensure that the frontend can parse and retrieve the authorization code or token from the URL parameters. For example, if your redirect URL is http://localhost:5173/?data=<token_data>, verify that your frontend code extracts data correctly.

  2. Parsing Query Parameters:

    • If your frontend expects the authorization token to be in a query parameter (e.g., ?data=...), ensure you have code that parses this parameter correctly. Here’s a quick example to retrieve data from the URL:
      javascript
      const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
const tokenData = urlParams.get('data');
if (tokenData) {
  // Process token data
  console.log("Token data:", JSON.parse(decodeURIComponent(tokenData)));
}

  3. Display Data Errors:

    • Based on the errors you shared, it seems the ShoeStatistics and LastRunData components are expecting certain props (shoeStats and lastRun) but are receiving null. This may happen if the frontend doesn’t properly set these props from the retrieved token data. Check to see if these props are being set correctly after obtaining the token data:
      javascript
      // Example of setting props based on token data
if (tokenData) {
  const { lastRun, gear } = JSON.parse(decodeURIComponent(tokenData));
  setLastRun(lastRun);
  setShoeStats(gear);
}

  4. Frontend State Management:

    • If you are using a state management solution (like React state or Redux), ensure the authorization data and token values are stored and updated correctly. After retrieving the token data, set it in the appropriate state:
      javascript
      const [lastRun, setLastRun] = useState(null);
const [shoeStats, setShoeStats] = useState(null);

useEffect(() => {
  if (tokenData) {
    const { lastRun, gear } = JSON.parse(decodeURIComponent(tokenData));
    setLastRun(lastRun);
    setShoeStats(gear);
  }
}, [tokenData]);

  5. Error Handling on Data Fetching:

    • If fetching additional data based on the token, make sure any errors in fetching are caught and displayed properly. For example:
      javascript
      useEffect(() => {
  if (accessToken) {
    fetchRuns(accessToken).catch(error => {
      console.error("Error fetching runs:", error);
    });
  }
}, [accessToken]);

  6. Network Request Errors:

    • If the frontend is making API requests (such as GET /api/runs), verify the request URL and headers are correctly set. For example, confirm that the Authorization header includes the Bearer prefix correctly:
      javascript
      axios.get("/api/runs", {
  headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}` },
});

Running through these steps should help you identify any issues with the frontend handling of Strava’s OAuth response or API data. Let me know if you need further clarification on any specific part!

    • The redirect URI registered on Strava matches exactly with what you're using in your application.
    • You’re receiving the authorization code in the handleAuthCallback function.

HOmepage.jsx import { Box, Grid } from "@mui/material"; import polyline from "@mapbox/polyline"; import UserInfo from "../components/user/UserInfo"; import WeeklyStatistics from "../components/run/WeeklyStatistics"; import ShoeStatistics from "../components/shoes/ShoeStatistics"; import LastRunData from "../components/run/LastRunData"; import shoeImage from "../assets/images/nike-structure.png"; import useFetchRunData from "../hooks/useFetchRunData"; export default function HomePage() { const state = useFetchRunData(); if (state.loading) return <div>Loading...</div>; const coordinates = state.lastRun?.summary_polyline ? polyline.decode(state.lastRun.summary_polyline) : []; const mapCenter = coordinates.length ? [coordinates[0][0], coordinates[0][1]] : [0, 0]; const formatDuration = (movingTimeString) => { if (!movingTimeString) return "N/A"; const minutesMatch = movingTimeString.match(/(\d+)\s*minutes/); if (minutesMatch) { const minutes = parseInt(minutesMatch[1], 10); return ${Math.floor(minutes / 60)}h ${minutes % 60}m; } return "N/A"; }; return ( <Box sx={{ p: 3, backgroundColor: "background.default" }}> <UserInfo username="UserName" /> <Grid container spacing={3}> <Grid item xs={12}> <WeeklyStatistics totalKilometersLastWeek={state.totalKilometersLastWeek} totalKilometersCurrentWeek={state.totalKilometersCurrentWeek} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <ShoeStatistics shoeStats={state.shoeStats} shoeImage={shoeImage} /> </Grid> <Grid item xs={12} md={6}> <LastRunData mapCenter={mapCenter} coordinates={coordinates} lastRun={state.lastRun} formatDuration={formatDuration} /> </Grid> </Grid> </Box> ); } .env REACT_APP_USE_DEMO_MODE=true REACT_APP_STRAVA_DEMO_TOKEN=2623039d8a4f21abb1a755d518a0adf85410d032 VITE_DEMO_RUNS_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/demo-runs VITE_RUNS_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/runs VITE_STRAVA_AUTH_URL=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava VITE_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/runs VITE_SHOES_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/shoes VITE_DEMO_RUNS_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/demo-all-runs VITE_DEMO_SHOES_API_URL=http://localhost:5000/api/demo-shoes useFetchRunData.js import { useState, useEffect } from "react"; import axios from "axios"; export default function useFetchRunData() { const [state, setState] = useState({ shoeStats: null, lastRun: null, totalKilometersLastWeek: 0, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: 0, loading: true, }); useEffect(() => { const fetchData = async () => { try { const url = import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_URL; const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search); const data = urlParams.get("data"); if (data) { const parsedData = JSON.parse(decodeURIComponent(data)); const accessToken = parsedData.accessToken; if (accessToken) { localStorage.setItem("accessToken", accessToken); } const response = await axios.get(url, { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, }); setState({ shoeStats: parsedData.gear, lastRun: { ...parsedData.lastRun, distance: parseFloat(parsedData.lastRun.distance), }, totalKilometersLastWeek: response.data.totalKilometersLastWeek, totalKilometersCurrentWeek: response.data.totalKilometersCurrentWeek, loading: false, }); } else { window.location.href = import.meta.env.VITE_STRAVA_AUTH_URL; } } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching run data:", error); setState((prevState) => ({ ...prevState, loading: false })); } }; fetchData(); }, []); return state; } useFetchRUns.js import { useEffect, useState } from "react"; import axios from "axios"; export const useFetchRuns = (currentPage) => { const [runs, setRuns] = useState([]); const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true); const [error, setError] = useState(null); const [totalRuns, setTotalRuns] = useState(0); const runsPerPage = 5; useEffect(() => { const fetchRuns = async () => { const accessToken = localStorage.getItem("accessToken"); if (!accessToken) { setError("Access token is missing. Please re-authenticate."); setLoading(false); return; } try { const response = await axios.get( ${import.meta.env.VITE_RUNS_API_URL}/activities?page=${currentPage}, { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} } } ); setRuns(response.data.runs); setTotalRuns(response.data.total); } catch (err) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", err); setError("Error fetching runs"); } finally { setLoading(false); } }; fetchRuns(); }, [currentPage]); return { runs, loading, error, totalRuns, runsPerPage }; }; AuthCOntext.jsx import { createContext, useState, useEffect } from "react"; import PropTypes from "prop-types"; export const AuthContext = createContext(null); export function AuthProvider({ children }) { const [token, setToken] = useState( localStorage.getItem("strava_token") || null ); useEffect(() => { if (token) { localStorage.setItem("strava_token", token); } else { localStorage.removeItem("strava_token"); } }, [token]); return ( <AuthContext.Provider value={{ token, setToken }}> {children} </AuthContext.Provider> ); } AuthProvider.propTypes = { children: PropTypes.node.isRequired, }; THese are my critical structure front end files , now ill provide backend

server.js require("dotenv").config(); const express = require("express"); const cors = require("cors"); const mongoose = require("mongoose"); const routes = require("./routes/indexRoutes"); const shoeRoutes = require("./routes/shoeRoutes"); const app = express(); const port = process.env.PORT || 5000; mongoose .connect(process.env.MONGODB_URI, {}) .then(() => console.log("MongoDB connected...")) .catch((err) => console.error("MongoDB connection error:", err)); app.use( cors({ origin: process.env.CORS_ORIGIN || "http://localhost:5173", credentials: true, }) ); app.use(express.json()); app.use("/api/shoes", shoeRoutes); app.use("/auth/strava", routes.stravaAuth); app.use("/api", routes.api); app.listen(port, () => { console.log(Server running on port ${port}); }); module.exports = app; .env file //Strava Application Settings STRAVA_CLIENT_ID=138288 STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET=50ac4dfa13bc7ae1919c9ca714e2ddb8df576b29 STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:5000/auth/strava/callback STRAVA_AUTH_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize STRAVA_TOKEN_URL=https://www.strava.com/oauth/token STRAVA_ACTIVITIES_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities STRAVA_ATHLETE_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete STRAVA_GEAR_URL=https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear //Refresh token STRAVA_REFRESH_TOKEN=e7955348cf80d466f20c1f3ed62b55b94351e2b5 // Tokens and Secrets ACCESS_TOKEN_SECRET=20e3f22377baa59ed5e9d9324d17edd684e2abd1 REFRESH_TOKEN_SECRET=e7955348cf80d466f20c1f3ed62b55b94351e2b5 // MongoDB Configuration MONGODB_URI=mongodb://localhost:27017/runtrackr // Frontend Configuration FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173 CORS_ORIGIN=http://localhost:5173 // Server Configuration PORT=5000 StaravaService.js const axios = require("axios"); const querystring = require("querystring"); /** * Generates the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @returns {string} - The authorization URL for Strava OAuth */ function generateAuthUrl() { const clientId = process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID; const redirectUri = process.env.STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI; return https://www.strava.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=${clientId}&response_type=code&redirect_uri=${redirectUri}&approval_prompt=force&scope=activity:read,profile:read_all; } /** * Exchanges an authorization code for an access token. * @param {string} authorizationCode - The authorization code from Strava * @returns {string} - The access token * @throws Will throw an error if the token exchange fails */ async function exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode) { try { const response = await axios.post( "https://www.strava.com/oauth/token", querystring.stringify({ client_id: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_ID, client_secret: process.env.STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET, code: authorizationCode, grant_type: "authorization_code", }) ); return response.data.access_token; } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); throw new Error("Failed to exchange authorization code for access token"); } } /** * Fetches the athlete's recent activities and returns the last run. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {Object} - Data for the last run * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the last run fails */ async function getLastRun(accessToken) { try { const response = await axios.get( "https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, params: { per_page: 10 }, } ); const lastRun = response.data.find((activity) => activity.type === "Run"); if (!lastRun) { return { message: "No run found in recent activities" }; } return { id: lastRun.id, name: lastRun.name, distance: (lastRun.distance / 1000).toFixed(2), moving_time: ${(lastRun.moving_time / 60).toFixed(0)} minutes, date: new Date(lastRun.start_date).toLocaleDateString(), summary_polyline: lastRun.map.summary_polyline, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching last run data:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run data from Strava"); } } /** * Fetches the athlete's profile to retrieve the primary shoe ID. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {string|null} - The ID of the primary shoe, or null if none found * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the athlete profile fails */ async function getAthleteProfile(accessToken) { try { const response = await axios.get("https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, }); return response.data.shoes?.[0]?.id || null; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching athlete profile:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch athlete profile from Strava"); } } /** * Fetches the details for a specific piece of gear (e.g., primary shoes). * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @param {string} gearId - ID of the gear to retrieve * @returns {Object} - Gear details including name and total mileage * @throws Will throw an error if fetching the gear details fails */ async function getGearDetails(accessToken, gearId) { try { const response = await axios.get( https://www.strava.com/api/v3/gear/${gearId}, { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, } ); return { name: response.data.name, totalMileage: ${(response.data.distance / 1000).toFixed(2)} km, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching gear details:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch gear details from Strava"); } } /** * Retrieves both the last run and gear details for an athlete. * @param {string} accessToken - Strava access token * @returns {Object} - Contains last run details and gear information * @throws Will throw an error if fetching either the last run or gear fails */ async function getLastRunAndGear(accessToken) { try { const lastRun = await getLastRun(accessToken); const gearId = await getAthleteProfile(accessToken); const gearDetails = gearId ? await getGearDetails(accessToken, gearId) : null; return { lastRun, gear: gearDetails || { message: "No gear found or no shoes set" }, }; } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching last run and gear data:", error); throw new Error("Failed to fetch last run and gear details from Strava"); } } module.exports = { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, }; activityService.js const axios = require("axios"); /** * Fetch activities from Strava API and filter for "Run" activities * @param {string} accessToken - User's access token * @returns {Array} - Array of running activities */ const fetchRunsData = async (accessToken) => { const response = await axios.get( "https://www.strava.com/api/v3/athlete/activities", { headers: { Authorization: Bearer ${accessToken} }, params: { per_page: 100, page: 1 }, } ); return response.data.filter((activity) => activity.type === "Run"); }; module.exports = { fetchRunsData }; StravaAccessController.js const { generateAuthUrl, exchangeAuthorizationCode, getLastRunAndGear, } = require("../services/stravaService"); /** * Redirects to the Strava OAuth authorization URL. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const getAuthUrl = (req, res) => { const authUrl = generateAuthUrl(); res.redirect(authUrl); }; /** * Handles the Strava OAuth callback, exchanges authorization code for access token, * and redirects to the frontend with user data. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const handleAuthCallback = async (req, res) => { const authorizationCode = req.query.code; if (!authorizationCode) { return res.status(400).json({ message: "Authorization code missing" }); } try { const accessToken = await exchangeAuthorizationCode(authorizationCode); console.log("Access Token:", accessToken); //debug const data = await getLastRunAndGear(accessToken); const redirectUri = ${process.env.FRONTEND_URL}/?data=${encodeURIComponent( JSON.stringify({ accessToken, lastRun: data.lastRun, gear: data.gear }) )}; res.redirect(redirectUri); } catch (error) { console.error("Error during token exchange:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Error during token exchange" }); } }; module.exports = { getAuthUrl, handleAuthCallback, }; Activity controller.js const { fetchRunsData } = require("../services/activityService"); const { calculateTotalKilometers } = require("../utils/dateUtils"); /** * Controller to fetch and return paginated runs, and calculate total kilometers for the last and current weeks. * @param {Object} req - Express request object * @param {Object} res - Express response object */ const fetchRuns = async (req, res) => { const accessToken = req.headers.authorization; const page = parseInt(req.query.page) || 1; const limit = 5; if (!accessToken) { return res.status(401).json({ message: "Access token is required" }); } try { const runs = await fetchRunsData(accessToken); const totalKilometersLastWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 7); const totalKilometersCurrentWeek = calculateTotalKilometers(runs, 0); const paginatedRuns = runs.slice((page - 1) * limit, page * limit); res.json({ runs: paginatedRuns, total: runs.length, totalKilometersLastWeek, totalKilometersCurrentWeek, }); } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching runs:", error); res.status(500).json({ message: "Failed to fetch runs from Strava API" }); } }; module.exports = { fetchRuns }; HERE IS MY FRONT END FROM LAST PROMT AND MY BACKEND WITH THIS PROMT , START DEBUGING THE CODE AND FIX THE PROBLEM ABOVE
„ChatGPT“ pasakė:

Thank you for sharing all the essential files. I'll begin with a structured debug process, primarily checking for alignment between the frontend, backend, and .env configuration. Based on the errors described, here’s the approach:

Key Issues Observed

  1. 401 Unauthorized Errors in accessing Strava API – indicates token issues.
  2. Frontend Fetch Errors – failures in data fetching, likely due to misalignment of authorization tokens.

I'll start by checking:

  1. Environment Variables – ensure all variables are correctly defined and accessed.
  2. Token Management – trace access token handling from OAuth to storage.
  3. Authorization Flow – ensure the frontend receives the token and that it’s properly managed in API calls.

Let’s address these systematically.

Step 1: Check .env Variables and Server Configuration

  • Ensure the .env variables in server.js and stravaService.js are consistently referenced.
  • Confirm that process.env is used appropriately to retrieve all variables:
    • STRAVA_CLIENT_ID
    • STRAVA_CLIENT_SECRET
    • STRAVA_REDIRECT_URI
    • STRAVA_TOKEN_URL
    • FRONTEND_URL

Step 2: Validate Strava OAuth Flow

In stravaService.js, the function generateAuthUrl constructs the URL for the OAuth process. To ensure consistency, confirm the URL is accessible by:

  • Logging the generated URL from generateAuthUrl() in the StravaAccessController.js where it’s called.
  • Testing the URL in a browser to verify it redirects to Strava and provides an authorization code.

Step 3: Authorization Code Exchange Debugging

The exchangeAuthorizationCode function is crucial in converting the authorization code to an access token.

  • Add Logs: Insert debug logs to track if the authorization code reaches this function.
  • Verify POST Data: Confirm that client_id, client_secret, code, and grant_type are accurately sent to STRAVA_TOKEN_URL.

Step 4: Access Token Usage in Frontend and Backend

Once an access token is obtained:

  • Check that exchangeAuthorizationCode returns a valid token.
  • Ensure the token is stored and retrieved correctly:
    • Frontend: Ensure localStorage access aligns with AuthContext.
    • Backend: Confirm Authorization headers include Bearer <token>.

Step 5: Debugging Backend Access with Token

The 401 error suggests the token may not be valid or correctly used.

  • Log Access Tokens: Print the token before each Strava API call to verify it matches the expected value.
  • Check Headers: Ensure Authorization: Bearer <accessToken> is set correctly.

Execution and Observations

I’ll go through these steps to analyze the current flow and identify specific areas to correct. Let’s begin, and I’ll keep you updated on each step.
